**Vilnius** ([/ˈvɪlniəs/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/a/ac/LL-Q1860_%28eng%29-Vealhurl-Vilnius.wav/LL-Q1860_%28eng%29-Vealhurl-Vilnius.wav.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:LL-Q1860_(eng)-Vealhurl-Vilnius.wav "File:LL-Q1860 (eng)-Vealhurl-Vilnius.wav")^ [*VIL-nee-əs*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key"),
Lithuanian: [\[ˈvʲɪlʲnʲʊs\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Lithuanian "Help:IPA/Lithuanian") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/0/03/Lt-Vilnius.oga/Lt-Vilnius.oga.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Lt-Vilnius.oga "File:Lt-Vilnius.oga")^) is the capital of and [largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Lithuania#Cities "List of cities in Lithuania") in [Lithuania](/wiki/Lithuania "Lithuania") and the [most-populous city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_the_Baltic_states_by_population "List of cities in the Baltic states by population") in the [Baltic states](/wiki/Baltic_states "Baltic states"). The city's estimated January 2025 population was 607,404,^[\[7\]](#cite_note-pop.lt-7)^ and the [Vilnius urban area](/wiki/Vilnius_urban_area "Vilnius urban area") (which extends beyond the city limits) has an estimated population of 747,864.^[\[8\]](#cite_note-FUA,Euro-8)^{#cite_ref-FUA,Euro_8-1}

Vilnius is notable for the architecture of its [Old Town](/wiki/Vilnius_Old_Town "Vilnius Old Town"), considered one of [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe")'s largest and best-preserved old towns. The city was declared a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") in 1994.^[\[13\]](#cite_note-archive.org-13)^^[\[14\]](#cite_note-TheCapital-14)^^[\[15\]](#cite_note-VWH-15)^^[\[16\]](#cite_note-Lurk-16)^ The architectural style known as [Vilnian Baroque](/wiki/Vilnian_Baroque "Vilnian Baroque") is named after the city, which is farthest to the east among [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture") cities and the largest such city north of the [Alps](/wiki/Alps "Alps").^[\[17\]](#cite_note-VilniusBaroqueVWH-17)^^[\[18\]](#cite_note-unesco-18)^{#cite_ref-unesco_18-0}

The city was noted for its [multicultural population](#Demographics) during the [Polish--Lithuanian Commonwealth](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth "Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth"), with contemporary sources comparing it to [Babylon](/wiki/Babylon "Babylon"). Before [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and [the Holocaust](/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Lithuania "The Holocaust in Lithuania"), Vilnius was one of Europe's most important Jewish centers. Its Jewish influence has led to its being called "the Jerusalem of Lithuania", and [Napoleon](/wiki/Napoleon "Napoleon") called it "the Jerusalem of the North"^[\[19\]](#cite_note-19)^ when he passed through in 1812.{#cite_ref-19}

Vilnius was a 2009 [European Capital of Culture](/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture "European Capital of Culture") with [Linz](/wiki/Linz "Linz") in Austria.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-20)^ In 2021, the city was named one of [fDi](/wiki/FDi_Intelligence "FDi Intelligence")'s 25 Global Cities of the Future.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-21)^ Vilnius is considered a global financial centre, ranked 76th globally and 29th in Europe on the [Global Financial Centres Index](/wiki/Global_Financial_Centres_Index "Global Financial Centres Index").^[\[22\]](#cite_note-22)^ The city is an important center for the global [fintech](/wiki/Fintech "Fintech") industry.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-23)^ It hosted the [2023 NATO Summit](/wiki/2023_Vilnius_summit "2023 Vilnius summit"). In 2025 Vilnius was the [European Green Capital](/wiki/European_Green_Capital "European Green Capital").^[\[24\]](#cite_note-24)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-25)^ Vilnius is a member of [Eurocities](/wiki/Eurocities "Eurocities")^[\[26\]](#cite_note-26)^ and the Union of Capitals of the European Union (UCEU).^[\[27\]](#cite_note-27)^{#cite_ref-27}  

Etymology and other names {#Etymology_and_other_names}
------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Etymology and other names")\]

Vilnius' name originates from the river [Vilnia](/wiki/Vilnia "Vilnia"), the Lithuanian word for *ripple* .^[\[28\]](#cite_note-28)^ Its name has had a number of derivative spellings in various languages throughout its history; *Vilna* was once common in English. The most notable non-Lithuanian names for the city include [Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language"): *Vilna* , [Polish](/wiki/Polish_language "Polish language"): *Wilno* , [Belarusian](/wiki/Belarusian_language "Belarusian language"): Вiльня (*Vilnia* ), [German](/wiki/German_language "German language"): *Wilna* , [Latvian](/wiki/Latvian_language "Latvian language"): *Viļņa* , [Ukrainian](/wiki/Ukrainian_language "Ukrainian language"): Вільно (*Vilno* ), [Yiddish](/wiki/Yiddish_language "Yiddish language"): ווילנע (*Vilne* ). A Russian name dating to the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") was Вильна (*Vilna* ),^[\[29\]](#cite_note-29)^^[\[30\]](#cite_note-30)^ although Вильнюс (*Vilnyus* ) is now used. The names *Wilno* , *Wilna* , and *Vilna* were used in English-, German-, French-, and Italian-language publications when the city was a capital of the [Polish--Lithuanian Commonwealth](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth "Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth") and an important city in the [Second Polish Republic](/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic "Second Polish Republic"). The name *Vilna* is still used in Finnish, Portuguese, Spanish, and [Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language"): וילנה. *Wilna* is still used in German alongside *Vilnius*.{#cite_ref-30}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Painting_depicting_the_Lithuanian_Grand_Duke_Gediminas%27_dream_about_an_Iron_Wolf_%28painted_by_Aleksander_Lesser_in_1835%29.jpg/180px-Painting_depicting_the_Lithuanian_Grand_Duke_Gediminas%27_dream_about_an_Iron_Wolf_%28painted_by_Aleksander_Lesser_in_1835%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Painting_depicting_the_Lithuanian_Grand_Duke_Gediminas%27_dream_about_an_Iron_Wolf_(painted_by_Aleksander_Lesser_in_1835).jpg) 1835 painting by [Aleksander Lesser](/wiki/Aleksander_Lesser "Aleksander Lesser") of Gediminas' dream about an Iron Wolf

According to a [legend](/wiki/Legend "Legend") [recorded](/wiki/Writing "Writing") during the  1530s, Grand Duke [Gediminas](/wiki/Gediminas "Gediminas") ( 1275--1341) was hunting in the sacred forest near [Šventaragis' Valley](/wiki/%C5%A0ventaragis%27_Valley "Šventaragis' Valley"), (where the Vilnia flows into the river [Neris](/wiki/Neris "Neris"). The successful [wisent](/wiki/European_bison "European bison") hunt lasted longer than expected, and Gediminas decided to spend the night in the valley. He fell asleep and dreamed of a huge [Iron Wolf](/wiki/Iron_Wolf_(character) "Iron Wolf (character)") at the top of a hill, howling loudly. Upon awakening, the Duke asked the *[krivis](/wiki/Kriwe "Kriwe")* [Lizdeika](/wiki/Lizdeika "Lizdeika") to interpret the dream. The chief priest told him:
> What is destined for the ruler and the State of Lithuania, is thus: the Iron Wolf [represents a castle](/wiki/Vilnius_Castle_Complex "Vilnius Castle Complex") and a city which will be established by you on this site. This city will be the capital of the Lithuanian lands and the dwelling of [their rulers](/wiki/List_of_heads_of_state_of_Lithuania "List of heads of state of Lithuania"), and the glory of their deeds shall echo throughout the world.

Gediminas, obeying [the gods](/wiki/List_of_Lithuanian_gods_and_mythological_figures "List of Lithuanian gods and mythological figures"), built two castles: the Lower Castle in the valley, and the Crooked Castle on [Bald Hill](/wiki/Three_Crosses "Three Crosses"). He moved his court there, declared it his permanent seat and capital, and developed the surrounding area into a city he named Vilnius.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-31)^^\[*[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")*\]^^[\[32\]](#cite_note-leg-32)^{#cite_ref-leg_32-0}  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Vilnius](/wiki/History_of_Vilnius "History of Vilnius")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Vilnius](/wiki/Timeline_of_Vilnius "Timeline of Vilnius").
[![A 14th-century manuscript](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Transcript_of_Gediminas%27_letter%2C_which_is_the_oldest_known_mentioning_of_Vilnius_in_written_sources_%2825_January_1323%29.jpg/220px-Transcript_of_Gediminas%27_letter%2C_which_is_the_oldest_known_mentioning_of_Vilnius_in_written_sources_%2825_January_1323%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Transcript_of_Gediminas%27_letter,_which_is_the_oldest_known_mentioning_of_Vilnius_in_written_sources_(25_January_1323).jpg) The oldest known mention of Vilnius, in Gediminas' 1323 [letter](/wiki/Letters_of_Gediminas "Letters of Gediminas") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Vilenskija_zamki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%96%D1%8F_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BA%D1%96_%28T._Mako%C5%ADski%2C_1600%29_%282%29.jpg/220px-Vilenskija_zamki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%96%D1%8F_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BA%D1%96_%28T._Mako%C5%ADski%2C_1600%29_%282%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilenskija_zamki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D1%96%D1%8F_%D0%B7%D0%B0%D0%BC%D0%BA%D1%96_(T._Mako%C5%ADski,_1600)_(2).jpg) [Vilnius Castle Complex](/wiki/Vilnius_Castle_Complex "Vilnius Castle Complex") in 1600 with the Upper Castle (marked as 7th), [Lower Castle](/wiki/Palace_of_the_Grand_Dukes_of_Lithuania "Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania") (6th), and [Cathedral](/wiki/Vilnius_Cathedral "Vilnius Cathedral") (5th)

Vilnius' history dates to the [Stone Age](/wiki/Stone_Age "Stone Age").^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^ The city at least since 1323 until 1795 had been the capital of the [Grand Duchy of Lithuania](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania "Grand Duchy of Lithuania"). Later Vilnius had been ruled by [imperial](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") and [Soviet Russia](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"), [Napoleonic France](/wiki/Napoleonic_France "Napoleonic France"), [imperial](/wiki/German_Empire "German Empire") and [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany"), [interwar Poland](/wiki/Interwar_Poland "Interwar Poland"), and again became a capital of Lithuania in the 20th century.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^{#cite_ref-ViVle_33-1}

Initially a [Baltic](/wiki/Balts "Balts") settlement, Vilnius became significant in the Grand Duchy of Lithuania.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^ The city was first mentioned in letters by Grand Duke [Gediminas](/wiki/Gediminas "Gediminas"), who invited Jews and Germans to settle and built a wooden castle on a hill.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^ Vilnius became a city in 1387, after the [Christianization of Lithuania](/wiki/Christianization_of_Lithuania "Christianization of Lithuania"), and was settled by craftsmen and merchants of a variety of nationalities.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^ It was the capital of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania (until 1795) within the [Polish--Lithuanian Commonwealth](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth "Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth").^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^ Vilnius flourished under the Commonwealth, especially after the 1579 establishment of [Vilnius University](/wiki/Vilnius_University "Vilnius University") by the Lithuanian Grand Duke [Stephen Báthory](/wiki/Stephen_B%C3%A1thory "Stephen Báthory").^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^ The city became a cultural and scientific center, attracting migrants from east and west.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^ It had diverse communities, with Jewish, Orthodox, and German populations.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^ The city experienced a number of invasions and occupations, including by the [Teutonic Knights](/wiki/Teutonic_Order "Teutonic Order"), Russia and, later, Germany.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^{#cite_ref-ViVle_33-9}

Under [imperial Russian rule](/wiki/Russian_partition "Russian partition"), Vilnius became the capital of [Vilna Governorate](/wiki/Vilna_Governorate "Vilna Governorate") and had a number of cultural revivals during the 19th and early 20th centuries by Jews, Poles, Lithuanians, and Belarusians.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^ [After World War I](/wiki/Second_Polish_Republic "Second Polish Republic"), the city experienced conflict between Poland and Lithuania which led to its occupation by Poland before its annexation by the Soviet Union during World War II.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^ After that war, Vilnius became the capital of the [Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic](/wiki/Lithuanian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic").^[\[33\]](#cite_note-ViVle-33)^{#cite_ref-ViVle_33-12}  

### Independence {#Independence}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Independence")\]
[![Modern Vilnius from a distance](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Vilnius_skyline.jpg/300px-Vilnius_skyline.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_skyline.jpg) The New City Centre seen from [Karoliniškės](/wiki/Karolini%C5%A1k%C4%97s "Karoliniškės"), with most of its [high-rise buildings](/wiki/High-rise_building "High-rise building") constructed within two decades of independence

On 11 March 1990, the [Supreme Council of the Lithuanian SSR](/wiki/Supreme_Soviet_of_the_Lithuanian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic") announced its [secession](/wiki/Act_of_the_Re-Establishment_of_the_State_of_Lithuania "Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania") from the Soviet Union and intention to restore an independent Lithuania.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-34)^ On 9 January 1991, the Soviet Union sent in troops; this culminated in the 13 January [attack](/wiki/January_Events "January Events") on the State Radio and Television Building and [Vilnius TV Tower](/wiki/Vilnius_TV_Tower "Vilnius TV Tower") which killed 14 civilians.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-35)^ The Soviet Union recognised Lithuanian independence in September 1991.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-36)^ According to the [Constitution of Lithuania](/wiki/Constitution_of_Lithuania "Constitution of Lithuania"), "the capital of the State of Lithuania shall be the city of Vilnius, the long-standing historical capital of Lithuania".{#cite_ref-36}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Panorama_Neris_-_Mount_Gediminas_%28cropped%29.jpg/300px-Panorama_Neris_-_Mount_Gediminas_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Panorama_Neris_-_Mount_Gediminas_(cropped).jpg) Post-independence construction in [Žirmūnai](/wiki/%C5%BDirm%C5%ABnai "Žirmūnai") on the Neris river's right bank

Vilnius has become a modern European city. Its territory has been expanded with [three acts](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lietuvos_administraciniai-teritoriniai_poky%C4%8Diai_1989%E2%80%932001_m.#Vilniaus_apskritis "lt:Lietuvos administraciniai-teritoriniai pokyčiai 1989–2001 m.") since 1990, incorporating urban areas, villages, hamlets, and the city of [Grigiškės](/wiki/Grigi%C5%A1k%C4%97s "Grigiškės").^[\[37\]](#cite_note-37)^^[\[38\]](#cite_note-38)^ Most historic buildings have been renovated and a business and commercial area became the [New City Centre](/wiki/Vilnius_Central_Business_District "Vilnius Central Business District"), the main administrative and business district on the north side of the river Neris. The area includes modern residential and retail space, with the municipal building and the 148.3 m (487 ft) [Europa Tower](/wiki/Europa_Tower "Europa Tower") its most prominent buildings. The construction of [Swedbank](/wiki/Swedbank "Swedbank")'s headquarters indicates the importance of [Scandinavian](/wiki/Scandinavia "Scandinavia") banks in Vilnius. The [Vilnius Business Harbour](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius_Business_Harbour&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vilnius Business Harbour (page does not exist)") complex was built and expanded. Over 75,000 flats were built from 1995 to 2018, making the city a Baltic construction leader.{#cite_ref-38}

Vilnius was selected as a 2009 [European Capital of Culture](/wiki/European_Capital_of_Culture "European Capital of Culture") with [Linz](/wiki/Linz "Linz"), the capital of [Upper Austria](/wiki/Upper_Austria "Upper Austria").^[\[39\]](#cite_note-39)^^[\[40\]](#cite_note-40)^ The [2007--2008 financial crisis](/wiki/2007%E2%80%932008_financial_crisis "2007–2008 financial crisis") led to a drop in tourism, which prevented many projects from completion; allegations of corruption and incompetence were made;^[\[41\]](#cite_note-41)^^[\[42\]](#cite_note-42)^ tax increases for cultural activity led to protests,^[\[43\]](#cite_note-43)^ and economic conditions sparked riots.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-44)^ On 28--29 November 2013, Vilnius hosted the [Eastern Partnership](/wiki/Eastern_Partnership "Eastern Partnership") summit at the [Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania](/wiki/Palace_of_the_Grand_Dukes_of_Lithuania "Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania"). Many European presidents, prime ministers, and high-ranking officials participated.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-45)^ In 2015, [Remigijus Šimašius](/wiki/Remigijus_%C5%A0ima%C5%A1ius "Remigijus Šimašius") became the city's first directly elected mayor.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-46)^ The [2023 NATO summit](/wiki/2023_Vilnius_summit "2023 Vilnius summit") was held in Vilnius.^[\[47\]](#cite_note-47)^{#cite_ref-47}  

Geography {#Nature_reserves}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Geography")\]
[![See caption](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Vilnius_skyline_-_Oct_14%2C_2019.jpg/220px-Vilnius_skyline_-_Oct_14%2C_2019.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_skyline_-_Oct_14,_2019.jpg) Aerial view of Vilnius City Centre and its surrounding green space [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Vilnia_2023b.jpg/220px-Vilnia_2023b.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnia_2023b.jpg) Rivers Vilnia and Neris confluence

Vilnius is at the [confluence](/wiki/Confluence "Confluence") of the [Vilnia](/wiki/Vilnia "Vilnia") and [Neris](/wiki/Neris "Neris") rivers in southeastern Lithuania. Several countries say that the [geographical midpoint of Europe](/wiki/Geographical_midpoint_of_Europe "Geographical midpoint of Europe") is within their territory. The midpoint depends on the definition of European extent, and the *[Guinness Book of World Records](/wiki/Guinness_Book_of_World_Records "Guinness Book of World Records")* recognises a point near Vilnius as the continental centre.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-gcentre-48)^ After a 1989 re-estimation of European boundaries, [Jean-George Affholder](/w/index.php?title=Jean-George_Affholder&action=edit&redlink=1 "Jean-George Affholder (page does not exist)") of the [Institut Géographique National](/wiki/Institut_g%C3%A9ographique_national_(France) "Institut géographique national (France)") (French National Geographic Institute) determined that its geographic centre was at [54°54′N 25°19′E﻿ / ﻿54.900°N 25.317°E﻿ / 54.900; 25.317﻿ (Purnuškės (centre of gravity))](https://geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Vilnius&params=54_54_N_25_19_E_type:landmark&title=Purnu%C5%A1k%C4%97s+%28centre+of+gravity%29).^[\[49\]](#cite_note-49)^ The method used to calculate the point was the [centre of gravity](/wiki/Centre_of_gravity "Centre of gravity") of the European [geometrical figure](/wiki/Geometry "Geometry"), and is near the village of [Girija](/wiki/Girija_(village) "Girija (village)") (26 kilometres from Vilnius). A monument by sculptor Gediminas Jokūbonis, a column of white granite surmounted by a crown of stars, was built there in 2004.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-gcentre-48)^{#cite_ref-gcentre_48-1}

Vilnius is 312 km (194 mi) from the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea") and [Klaipėda](/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da "Klaipėda"), the main Lithuanian [seaport](/wiki/Port "Port"). It is connected by road to other major Lithuanian cities, such as Kaunas (102 km or 63 mi away), [Šiauliai](/wiki/%C5%A0iauliai "Šiauliai") (214 km or 133 mi away) and [Panevėžys](/wiki/Panev%C4%97%C5%BEys "Panevėžys") (135 km or 84 mi away).

Vilnius has an area of 402 km^2^ (155 sq mi). Buildings cover 29.1 percent of the city; green space covers 68.8 percent, and water covers 2.1 percent.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-50)^ The city has eight [nature reserves](/wiki/Nature_reserve "Nature reserve"): Vokės Senslėnio Slopes Geomorphological Reserve, Aukštagiris Geomorphological Reserve, Valakupių Klonio Geomorphological Reserve, Veržuva Hydrographic Reserve, Vokė Hydrographic Reserve, Cedronas Upstream Landscape Reserve, Tapeliai Landscape Reserve, and Šeškinė Slopes Geomorphological Reserve.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-51)^{#cite_ref-51}

Several lakes, including [Balžis](/wiki/Bal%C5%BEis "Balžis"), are located on the north-eastern outskirts of Vilnius.  

Climate {#Climate}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Climate")\]
[![Aerial view of the city](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Foggy_Winter_Sunrise_in_Vilnius.jpg/220px-Foggy_Winter_Sunrise_in_Vilnius.jpg)](/wiki/File:Foggy_Winter_Sunrise_in_Vilnius.jpg) A foggy winter sunrise [![A busy, cobbled city street](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Gediminas_Avenue_in_autumn.jpg/220px-Gediminas_Avenue_in_autumn.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gediminas_Avenue_in_autumn.jpg) [Gediminas Avenue](/wiki/Gediminas_Avenue "Gediminas Avenue") in autumn

Vilnius has a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") ([Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification") *Dfb* ),^[\[52\]](#cite_note-52)^ with temperature records since 1777.^[\[53\]](#cite_note-53)^ The average annual temperature is 7.3 °C (45 °F); the average January temperature is −3.9 °C (25 °F), and the July average is 18.7 °C (66 °F). Average annual [precipitation](/wiki/Precipitation "Precipitation") is 691 mm (27.20 in). Temperatures in the city have increased significantly during the last 30 years, a change which the [Lithuanian Hydrometeorological Service](/wiki/Lithuanian_Hydrometeorological_Service "Lithuanian Hydrometeorological Service") attributes to human-induced [global warming](/wiki/Global_warming "Global warming").^[\[54\]](#cite_note-meteo-54)^{#cite_ref-meteo_54-0}

Summer days are warm to hot, especially in July and August, with daytime temperatures above 30 °C (86 °F) during periodic heat waves. Outdoor bars, restaurants and cafés are frequented during the day.

Winters can be very cold, although temperatures above 0 °C (32 °F); still occasionally occur. Temperatures below −25 °C (−13 °F) are recorded every other year. Vilnius's rivers freeze in particularly cold winters, and the lakes surrounding the city are almost always frozen from December to March, and even April, in the most extreme years. The Lithuanian Hydrometeorological Service, headquartered in Vilnius, monitors the country's climate.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-55)^{#cite_ref-55}
