Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Culture")\]  

### Painting and sculpture {#Painting_and_sculpture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Painting and sculpture")\]
[![A large wall painting](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Bernardinerkirche_Vilnius_1.jpg/220px-Bernardinerkirche_Vilnius_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bernardinerkirche_Vilnius_1.jpg) 16th-century Gothic frescoes in the Church of St. Francis and St. Bernard [![Ornate brown marble sculpture](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Tombstone_for_Leonas_Sapiega01%28js%29.jpg/130px-Tombstone_for_Leonas_Sapiega01%28js%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tombstone_for_Leonas_Sapiega01(js).jpg) Tombstone of Lew Sapieha, 1633, in the Church of St. Michael

Vilnius was an artistic centre of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, attracting artists across Europe. The oldest surviving early [Gothic](/wiki/Gothic_art "Gothic art") artworks (14th century) are paintings dedicated to churches and [liturgy](/wiki/Liturgy "Liturgy"), such as frescoes in the crypts of [Vilnius Cathedral](/wiki/Vilnius_Cathedral "Vilnius Cathedral") and decorated [hymnbooks](/wiki/Hymnal "Hymnal"). Sixteenth-century wall paintings are in the city's [Church of St. Francis and St. Bernard](/wiki/Church_of_St._Francis_and_St._Bernard,_Vilnius "Church of St. Francis and St. Bernard, Vilnius") and the [Church of Saint Nicholas](/wiki/Church_of_Saint_Nicholas,_Vilnius "Church of Saint Nicholas, Vilnius").^[\[61\]](#cite_note-tapybavle-61)^ Gothic wooden polychrome sculptures decorate church altars. Some Gothic [seals](/wiki/Seal_(emblem) "Seal (emblem)") from the 14th and 15th centuries still exist, including those of [Kęstutis](/wiki/K%C4%99stutis "Kęstutis"), [Vytautas the Great](/wiki/Vytautas_the_Great "Vytautas the Great") and [Sigismund II Augustus](/wiki/Sigismund_II_Augustus "Sigismund II Augustus").^[\[62\]](#cite_note-skulptura-62)^{#cite_ref-skulptura_62-0}

[Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance") sculpture appeared during the early 16th century, primarily by the [Italian](/wiki/Italy "Italy") sculptors Bernardinus Zanobi da Gianotti, Giovani Cini, and Giovanni Maria Padovano. During the Renaissance, portrait tombstones and medals were valued; examples are the marble tombs of [Albertas Goštautas](/wiki/Albertas_Go%C5%A1tautas "Albertas Goštautas") (1548) and [Paweł Holszański](/wiki/Pawe%C5%82_Holsza%C5%84ski "Paweł Holszański") (1555) by [Bernardino de Gianotis](/wiki/Bernardino_de_Gianotis "Bernardino de Gianotis") in Vilnius Cathedral. Italian sculpture is characterized by its naturalistic treatment of forms and precise proportions. Local sculptors adopted the iconographic scheme of Renaissance tombs; their works, such the tomb of [Lew Sapieha](/wiki/Lew_Sapieha "Lew Sapieha") ( 1633) in the [Church of St. Michael](/wiki/Church_of_St._Michael,_Vilnius "Church of St. Michael, Vilnius"), are stylized.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-skulptura-62)^ During this period, local and [Western European](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe") painters created religious and mythological compositions and portraits with late Gothic and Baroque features; illustrated prayerbooks, illustrations, and miniatures have survived.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-tapybavle-61)^{#cite_ref-tapybavle_61-1}

During the late-16th-century [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque"), wall painting developed. Most palaces and churches were decorated in frescoes with bright colors, sophisticated angles, and drama. Secular painting -- representational, imaginative, epitaph portraits, scenes of battles and politically important events in a detailed, realistic style -- also spread at this time.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-tapybavle-61)^ Baroque sculptures dominated [sacred architecture](/wiki/Sacred_architecture "Sacred architecture"): tombstones with sculpted portraits and decorative sculptures in wood, marble, and [stucco](/wiki/Stucco "Stucco"). Italian sculptors such as G. P. Perti, G. M. Galli, and A. S. Capone, key figures in the development of sculpture in the 17th-century grand duchy, were commissioned by [Lithuanian nobility](/wiki/Lithuanian_nobility "Lithuanian nobility"). Their works exemplify the mature Baroque, with expressive forms and sensuality. Local sculptors emphasized Baroque decorative features, with less expression and emotion.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-skulptura-62)^{#cite_ref-skulptura_62-2}
[![Painting of a young woman](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Rusiecki-Litwinka_z_wierzbami.jpg/140px-Rusiecki-Litwinka_z_wierzbami.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rusiecki-Litwinka_z_wierzbami.jpg) *[Lithuanian Girl with Palm Sunday Fronds](/wiki/Lithuanian_Girl_with_Palm_Sunday_Fronds "Lithuanian Girl with Palm Sunday Fronds")* by [Kanuty Rusiecki](/wiki/Kanuty_Rusiecki "Kanuty Rusiecki")

Lithuanian painting was influenced by the [Vilnius Art School](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vilniaus_meno_mokykla "lt:Vilniaus meno mokykla") during the late 18th and 19th centuries, which introduced [classical](/wiki/Classicism "Classicism") and [romantic](/wiki/Romanticism "Romanticism") art. Painters had internships abroad, mainly in Italy. Allegorical, mythological compositions, landscapes, and portraits of representatives of various circles of society began, and historical themes prevailed. The era's best-known classical painters are [Franciszek Smaglewicz](/w/index.php?title=Franciszek_Smaglewicz&action=edit&redlink=1 "Franciszek Smaglewicz (page does not exist)"), [Jan Rustem](/wiki/Jan_Rustem "Jan Rustem"), [Józef Oleszkiew](/w/index.php?title=J%C3%B3zef_Oleszkiew&action=edit&redlink=1 "Józef Oleszkiew (page does not exist)"), [Daniel Kondratowicz](/w/index.php?title=Daniel_Kondratowicz&action=edit&redlink=1 "Daniel Kondratowicz (page does not exist)") \[[pl](https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Kondratowicz "pl:Daniel Kondratowicz")\], [Józef Peszka](/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Peszka "Józef Peszka"), and [Wincenty Smokowski](/wiki/Wincenty_Smokowski "Wincenty Smokowski"). Romantic artists were Jan Rustem, [Jan Krzysztof Damel](/wiki/Jan_Krzysztof_Damel "Jan Krzysztof Damel"), [Wincenty Dmochowski](/wiki/Wincenty_Dmochowski "Wincenty Dmochowski") and [Kanuty Rusiecki](/wiki/Kanuty_Rusiecki "Kanuty Rusiecki").^[\[61\]](#cite_note-tapybavle-61)^ After the 1832 closure of Vilnius University, the Vilnius Art School continued to influence Lithuanian art.^[\[63\]](#cite_note-63)^{#cite_ref-63}

The [Lithuanian Art Society](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lietuvi%C5%B3_dail%C4%97s_draugija "lt:Lietuvių dailės draugija") was established in 1907 by [Petras Rimša](/wiki/Petras_Rim%C5%A1a "Petras Rimša"), [Antanas Žmuidzinavičius](/wiki/Antanas_%C5%BDmuidzinavi%C4%8Dius "Antanas Žmuidzinavičius") and [Antanas Jaroševičius](/wiki/Antanas_Jaro%C5%A1evi%C4%8Dius "Antanas Jaroševičius"), and the Vilnius Art Society was founded the following year.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-64)^^[\[65\]](#cite_note-65)^ Artists included Jonas Šileika, [Justinas Vienožinskis](/w/index.php?title=Justinas_Vieno%C5%BEinskis&action=edit&redlink=1 "Justinas Vienožinskis (page does not exist)") \[[lt](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justinas_Vieno%C5%BEinskis "lt:Justinas Vienožinskis")\], [Jonas Mackevičius (1872)](/w/index.php?title=Jonas_Mackevi%C4%8Dius_(1872)&action=edit&redlink=1 "Jonas Mackevičius (1872) (page does not exist)") \[[lt](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonas_Mackevi%C4%8Dius "lt:Jonas Mackevičius")\], [Vytautas Kairiūkštis](/wiki/Vytautas_Kairi%C5%ABk%C5%A1tis "Vytautas Kairiūkštis"), and [Vytautas Pranas Bičiūnas](/wiki/Vytautas_Pranas_Bi%C4%8Di%C5%ABnas "Vytautas Pranas Bičiūnas"), who employed Western European [symbolism](/wiki/Symbolism_(arts) "Symbolism (arts)"), [realism](/wiki/Realism_(arts) "Realism (arts)"), [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") and [modernism](/wiki/Modernism "Modernism").^[\[61\]](#cite_note-tapybavle-61)^ [Socialist realism](/wiki/Socialist_realism "Socialist realism") was introduced after [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), with [propaganda](/wiki/Propaganda "Propaganda") paintings, historical and household works, [still lives](/wiki/Still_life "Still life"), landscapes, portraits, and sculptures.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-tapybavle-61)^^[\[62\]](#cite_note-skulptura-62)^ Late 20th- and 21st-century painters are Žygimantas Augustinas, Eglė Ridikaitė, Eglė Gineitytė, Patricija Jurkšaitytė, Jurga Barilaitė, and Solomonas Teitelbaumas.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-tapybavle-61)^{#cite_ref-tapybavle_61-6}

The [Užupis](/wiki/U%C5%BEupis "Užupis") district near the Old Town, a run-down district during the Soviet era, hosts bohemian artists who operate a number of art galleries and workshops.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-66)^ In its main square, a statue of an angel blowing a trumpet symbolises artistic freedom.{#cite_ref-66}

The world's first bronze memorial to [Frank Zappa](/wiki/Frank_Zappa "Frank Zappa")^[\[67\]](#cite_note-67)^ was installed in the [Naujamiestis](/wiki/Naujamiestis,_Vilnius "Naujamiestis, Vilnius") district in 1995. In 2015, the Vilnius Talking Statues project was introduced. Eighteen statues around the city interact by smartphone with visitors in several languages.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-68)^{#cite_ref-68}  

### Museums and galleries {#Museums_and_galleries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Museums and galleries")\]  
See also: [List of museums in Lithuania](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Lithuania "List of museums in Lithuania")
[![Long, two-story building with a red roof](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Vilnius_-_Lietuvos_nacionalinis_muziejus.jpg/220px-Vilnius_-_Lietuvos_nacionalinis_muziejus.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_-_Lietuvos_nacionalinis_muziejus.jpg) The National Museum of Lithuania is in the New Arsenal of the Vilnius Castle Complex.

Vilnius has a variety of museums.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-GoVilniusMuseums-69)^ The [National Museum of Lithuania](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Lithuania "National Museum of Lithuania"), in the Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania, Gediminas' Tower and the arsenals of the Vilnius Castle Complex, has exhibits about the history of Lithuania and Lithuanian culture.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-70)^^[\[71\]](#cite_note-71)^^[\[72\]](#cite_note-72)^ The Museum of Applied Arts and Design displays Lithuanian folk and religious art, objects from the Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania, and 18th- to 20th-century clothing.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-73)^ Other museums are the Vilnius Museum, the House of Histories, Church Heritage Museum, [Museum of Occupations and Freedom Fights](/wiki/Museum_of_Occupations_and_Freedom_Fights "Museum of Occupations and Freedom Fights"), Fight for Freedom Museum in the [Vilnius TV Tower](/wiki/Vilnius_TV_Tower "Vilnius TV Tower"), M. K. Čiurlionis House, Samuel Bak Museum, Centre for Civil Education, Toy Museum, Vilnil (Museum of Illusions), Energy and Technology Museum, House of Signatories, Tolerance Center, Railway Museum, Money Museum, Kazys Varnelis House-Museum, Liubavas Manor Watermill-Museum, Museum of Vladislovas Sirokomlė, Amber Museum-Gallery, and the Paneriai Memorial visitor information centre.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-GoVilniusMuseums-69)^^[\[74\]](#cite_note-74)^{#cite_ref-74}
[![Exterior of a three-story building](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Art_Museum_of_Lithuania.jpg/220px-Art_Museum_of_Lithuania.jpg)](/wiki/File:Art_Museum_of_Lithuania.jpg) The Lithuanian National Museum of Art, in the former [Chodkiewicz Palace](/wiki/Chodkiewicz_Palace "Chodkiewicz Palace")

Vilnius has a number of art galleries. Lithuania's largest art collection is housed in the [Lithuanian National Museum of Art](/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Museum_of_Art "Lithuanian National Museum of Art").^[\[75\]](#cite_note-75)^ The Vilnius Picture Gallery, in the city's Old Town, houses a collection of Lithuanian art from the 16th to the early 20th centuries.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-76)^ Across the Neris, the National Art Gallery has a number of exhibitions of 20th-century Lithuanian art.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-77)^ The [Contemporary Art Centre](/wiki/Contemporary_Art_Centre_(Vilnius) "Contemporary Art Centre (Vilnius)"), the largest contemporary-art venue in the Baltic States, has an exhibition space of 2,400 square metres (26,000 sq ft). The centre develops international and Lithuanian exhibitions and presents a range of public programs which include lectures, seminars, performances, film and video screenings, and live music.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-78)^ On 10 November 2007, the [Jonas Mekas Visual Arts Center](/wiki/Jonas_Mekas_Visual_Arts_Center "Jonas Mekas Visual Arts Center") was opened by avant-garde filmmaker [Jonas Mekas](/wiki/Jonas_Mekas "Jonas Mekas"); its premiere exhibition was *The Avant-Garde: From [Futurism](/wiki/Futurism "Futurism") to [Fluxus](/wiki/Fluxus "Fluxus")* .^[\[79\]](#cite_note-79)^ In 2018, the [MO Museum](/wiki/MO_Museum "MO Museum") opened as an initiative of Lithuanian scientists and philanthropists Danguolė and Viktoras Butkus. Its collection of 5,000 modern pieces includes major Lithuanian artworks from the 1950s to the present.^[\[80\]](#cite_note-80)^{#cite_ref-80}  

### Literature {#Literature}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Literature")\]  
See also: [Lithuanian literature](/wiki/Lithuanian_literature "Lithuanian literature")
[![Old photo of a store exterior](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Zawadzki_bookstore_in_Vilnius.jpg/220px-Zawadzki_bookstore_in_Vilnius.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zawadzki_bookstore_in_Vilnius.jpg) The Zawadzki bookstore, on present-day [Pilies Street](/wiki/Pilies_Street "Pilies Street"). Its signs are in Russian, Polish, Lithuanian, French, and German.

Around 1520, [Francysk Skaryna](/wiki/Francysk_Skaryna "Francysk Skaryna") (author of the first Ruthenian [Bible](/wiki/Bible "Bible")) established [eastern Europe](/wiki/Eastern_Europe "Eastern Europe")'s first [printing house](/wiki/Printing_house "Printing house") in Vilnius. Skaryna prepared and published the *Little Traveller's Book* (Ruthenian: *Малая подорожная книжка* ), the first printed book of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, in 1522. Three years later, he printed the *Acts and Epistles of the Apostles* (the *Apostle* ).^[\[81\]](#cite_note-81)^{#cite_ref-81}

The [Vilnius Academy Press](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vilniaus_akademijos_spaustuv%C4%97 "lt:Vilniaus akademijos spaustuvė") was established in 1575 by Lithuanian nobleman [Mikołaj Krzysztof "the Orphan" Radziwiłł](/wiki/Miko%C5%82aj_Krzysztof_%22the_Orphan%22_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82 "Mikołaj Krzysztof \"the Orphan\" Radziwiłł") as the [Vilnius Academy](/wiki/Vilnius_Academy "Vilnius Academy") printing house, delegating its management to the [Jesuits](/wiki/Jesuits "Jesuits"). It published its first book, [Piotr Skarga](/wiki/Piotr_Skarga "Piotr Skarga")'s *Pro Sacratissima Eucharistia contra haeresim Zwinglianam* , in May 1576. The press was funded by the Lithuanian nobility and the church.^[\[82\]](#cite_note-82)^ In 1805, [Józef Zawadzki](/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Zawadzki_(publisher) "Józef Zawadzki (publisher)") bought the press and founded the [Józef Zawadzki printing shop](/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Zawadzki_printing_shop "Józef Zawadzki printing shop"). Operating continuously until 1939, it published books in a number of languages;^[\[83\]](#cite_note-83)^ [Adam Mickiewicz](/wiki/Adam_Mickiewicz "Adam Mickiewicz")'s first poetry book was published in 1822.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-84)^{#cite_ref-84}

[Mikalojus Daukša](/wiki/Mikalojus_Dauk%C5%A1a "Mikalojus Daukša") translated and published a [catechism](/wiki/Catechism "Catechism") by Spanish Jesuit theologian [Jacobo Ledesma](/w/index.php?title=Jacobo_Ledesma&action=edit&redlink=1 "Jacobo Ledesma (page does not exist)") in 1595, the first printed Lithuanian-language book in the Grand Duchy of Lithuania. He also translated and published [Jakub Wujek](/wiki/Jakub_Wujek "Jakub Wujek")'s *[Postilla](/wiki/Postilla "Postilla") Catholica* in 1599.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-85)^{#cite_ref-85}
[![Exterior of a large church](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Gate_of_the_Greek_Catholic_Church_of_Holy_Trinity_in_Vilnius_in_2013.jpg/220px-Gate_of_the_Greek_Catholic_Church_of_Holy_Trinity_in_Vilnius_in_2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gate_of_the_Greek_Catholic_Church_of_Holy_Trinity_in_Vilnius_in_2013.jpg) Gate of the [Basilian Monastery](/wiki/Basilian_Monastery_in_Vilnius "Basilian Monastery in Vilnius"), where Adam Mickiewicz was imprisoned for fighting [Russian rule](/wiki/Russian_Partition "Russian Partition")

Many writers were born in Vilnius, lived there, or are [alumni](/wiki/Alumni "Alumni") of Vilnius University; they include [Konstantinas Sirvydas](/wiki/Konstantinas_Sirvydas "Konstantinas Sirvydas"), [Maciej Kazimierz Sarbiewski](/wiki/Maciej_Kazimierz_Sarbiewski "Maciej Kazimierz Sarbiewski"), [Antoni Gorecki](/wiki/Antoni_Gorecki "Antoni Gorecki"), [Józef Ignacy Kraszewski](/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Ignacy_Kraszewski "Józef Ignacy Kraszewski"), [Antoni Edward Odyniec](/wiki/Antoni_Edward_Odyniec "Antoni Edward Odyniec"), [Michał Józef Römer](/wiki/Micha%C5%82_J%C3%B3zef_R%C3%B6mer "Michał Józef Römer"), Adam Mickiewicz, [Władysław Syrokomla](/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_Syrokomla "Władysław Syrokomla"), [Józef Mackiewicz](/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Mackiewicz "Józef Mackiewicz"), [Romain Gary](/wiki/Romain_Gary "Romain Gary"), [Juliusz Słowacki](/wiki/Juliusz_S%C5%82owacki "Juliusz Słowacki"), [Simonas Daukantas](/wiki/Simonas_Daukantas "Simonas Daukantas"), [Mykolas Biržiška](/wiki/Mykolas_Bir%C5%BEi%C5%A1ka "Mykolas Biržiška"), [Petras Cvirka](/wiki/Petras_Cvirka "Petras Cvirka"), [Kazys Bradūnas](/wiki/Kazys_Brad%C5%ABnas "Kazys Bradūnas"), [Nobel laureate](/wiki/Nobel_Prize "Nobel Prize") [Czesław Miłosz](/wiki/Czes%C5%82aw_Mi%C5%82osz "Czesław Miłosz").^[\[86\]](#cite_note-86)^ [Vilnius Academy of Arts](/wiki/Vilnius_Academy_of_Arts "Vilnius Academy of Arts") alumnae have also added to the internationally acclaimed contemporary writers such as [Jurga Ivanauskaitė](/wiki/Jurga_Ivanauskait%C4%97 "Jurga Ivanauskaitė"), [Undinė Radzevičiūtė](/wiki/Undin%C4%97_Radzevi%C4%8Di%C5%ABt%C4%97 "Undinė Radzevičiūtė") and [Kristina Sabaliauskaitė](/wiki/Kristina_Sabaliauskait%C4%97 "Kristina Sabaliauskaitė"). The first consideration of the [First Statute of Lithuania](/wiki/Statutes_of_Lithuania "Statutes of Lithuania") took place in 1522 at the [Seimas of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania](/wiki/Seimas_of_the_Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania "Seimas of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania"). The code was drafted under the guidance of [Grand Chancellor of Lithuania](/wiki/Grand_Chancellor_of_Lithuania "Grand Chancellor of Lithuania") Albertas Goštautas in accordance with [customary law](/wiki/Customary_law "Customary law"), legislation, and [canon](/wiki/Canon_law "Canon law") and [Roman law](/wiki/Roman_law "Roman law"). It is Europe's first [codification](/wiki/Codification_(law) "Codification (law)") of [secular law](/wiki/Secular_law "Secular law").^[\[87\]](#cite_note-87)^ Albertas Goštautas supported the use of Lithuanian in literature and protected Lithuanian authors (including [Abraomas Kulvietis](/wiki/Abraomas_Kulvietis "Abraomas Kulvietis") and [Michael the Lithuanian](/wiki/Michael_the_Lithuanian "Michael the Lithuanian")) who criticised the use of [Old Church Slavonic](/wiki/Old_Church_Slavonic "Old Church Slavonic"), and called refugees [Old Believers](/wiki/Old_Believers "Old Believers") in *[De moribus tartarorum, lituanorum et moscorum](/wiki/De_moribus_tartarorum,_lituanorum_et_moscorum "De moribus tartarorum, lituanorum et moscorum")* .^[\[88\]](#cite_note-Dubonis2002-88)^{#cite_ref-Dubonis2002_88-0}
[![Exterior of a square, white building](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Vileishis_Palace1.jpg/220px-Vileishis_Palace1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vileishis_Palace1.jpg) The Institute of Lithuanian Literature and Folklore in [Vileišis Palace](/wiki/Vilei%C5%A1is_Palace "Vileišis Palace")

Since the 16th century, the [Lithuanian Metrica](/wiki/Lithuanian_Metrica "Lithuanian Metrica") has been kept at the [Lower Castle](/wiki/Royal_Palace_of_Lithuania "Royal Palace of Lithuania") and safeguarded by the State [Chancellor](/wiki/Chancellor "Chancellor"). Due to the deterioration of the books, Grand Chancellor Lew Sapieha ordered the Metrica recopied in 1594; the recopying continued until 1607. The recopied books were inventoried, rechecked, and transferred to a separate building in Vilnius; the older books remained in the Castle of Vilnius. According to 1983 data, 665 books remain on [microfilm](/wiki/Microfilm "Microfilm") at the Lithuanian State Historical Archives in Vilnius.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-89)^{#cite_ref-89}

Over 200 tiles and plaques commemorating writers who lived and worked in Vilnius and foreign authors connected to Vilnius and Lithuania adorn walls on [Literatų Street](/wiki/Literat%C5%B3_Street "Literatų Street") (Lithuanian: *Literatų gatvė* ) in the Old Town, outlining the history of Lithuanian literature.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-90)^ The [Institute of Lithuanian Literature and Folklore](/wiki/Institute_of_Lithuanian_Literature_and_Folklore "Institute of Lithuanian Literature and Folklore") and the [Lithuanian Writers' Union](/wiki/Lithuanian_Writers%27_Union "Lithuanian Writers' Union") are in the city.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-91)^^[\[92\]](#cite_note-92)^ The [Vilnius book fair](/wiki/Vilnius_book_fair "Vilnius book fair") is held annually at [LITEXPO](/wiki/LITEXPO "LITEXPO"), the Baltics' largest exhibition centre.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-93)^{#cite_ref-93}  

### Cinema {#Cinema}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Cinema")\]  
See also: [Cinema of Lithuania](/wiki/Cinema_of_Lithuania "Cinema of Lithuania")
[![Exterior of the Botanical Garden gate](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Billboard_of_the_first_cinema_screening_in_Vilnius_%281897%29.jpg/220px-Billboard_of_the_first_cinema_screening_in_Vilnius_%281897%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Billboard_of_the_first_cinema_screening_in_Vilnius_(1897).jpg) Billboard above the Botanical Garden main gate of the first film screening in Vilnius (1896)

The first public [film session](/wiki/Film_session "Film session") in Vilnius was held in the Botanical Garden (now the [Bernardinai Garden](/wiki/Bernardinai_Garden "Bernardinai Garden")) in July 1896. It was held after 1895 film sessions by [Auguste and Louis Lumière](/wiki/Auguste_and_Louis_Lumi%C3%A8re "Auguste and Louis Lumière") in Paris. The session in Vilnius showed the Lumière brothers' [documentary](/wiki/Documentary "Documentary") films. The first films shown were educational, filmed outside Vilnius (in India and Africa), and introduced other cultures. [Georges Méliès](/wiki/Georges_M%C3%A9li%C3%A8s "Georges Méliès")' film, *[A Trip to the Moon](/wiki/A_Trip_to_the_Moon "A Trip to the Moon")* , was first shown at the [Lukiškės Square](/wiki/Luki%C5%A1k%C4%97s_Square "Lukiškės Square") movie theater in 1902; it was the first [feature film](/wiki/Feature_film "Feature film") shown in Vilnius.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-cinemaLRT-94)^{#cite_ref-cinemaLRT_94-0}

The first [movie theater](/wiki/Movie_theater "Movie theater") in Vilnius, Iliuzija (Illusion), opened in 1905 at 60 [Didžioji Street](/wiki/Did%C5%BEioji_Street "Didžioji Street").^[\[95\]](#cite_note-cinemaMIV-95)^ The first movie theaters, similar to theatres, had [boxes](/wiki/Box_(theatre) "Box (theatre)") with more-expensive seats. Because early films were silent, showings were accompanied by orchestral performances. Cinema screenings were sometimes combined with theatrical performances and illusion shows.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-cinemaLRT-94)^{#cite_ref-cinemaLRT_94-1}
[![A large, white, two-story building](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/LTMKM_2023_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg/220px-LTMKM_2023_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg)](/wiki/File:LTMKM_2023_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg) The [Lithuanian Theater, Music and Cinema Museum](/wiki/Lithuanian_Theater,_Music_and_Cinema_Museum "Lithuanian Theater, Music and Cinema Museum"), in the 17th-century [Minor Radvilos Palace](/wiki/Minor_Radvilos_Palace "Minor Radvilos Palace")

On 4 June 1924, the Vilnius [magistrate](/wiki/Magistrate "Magistrate") established a 1,200-seat movie theater in the city hall ([Polish](/wiki/Polish_language "Polish language"): *Miejski kinematograf* , City Movie Theater) to provide cultural education for students and adults. In 1926, 502,261 tickets were sold; 24,242 tickets were given to boarding children, 778 to tourists, and 8,385 to soldiers. In 1939, Lithuanian authorities renamed it Milda. The last city government gave it to the People's Commissariat of Education, which established the Lithuanian National Philharmonic Society, the following year.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-cinemaMIV-95)^{#cite_ref-cinemaMIV_95-1}

In 1965, Lithuania's most modern movie theater ([Lietuva](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lietuva_(kino_teatras) "lt:Lietuva (kino teatras)")) opened in Vilnius; it had over 1.84 million visitors per year, and an annual profit of over 1 million [roubles](/wiki/Soviet_rouble "Soviet rouble"). After reconstruction, it had one of Europe's largest screens: 200 square metres (2,200 sq ft).^[\[95\]](#cite_note-cinemaMIV-95)^ Closed in 2002, it was demolished in 2017 and replaced by MO Museum.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-96)^ Kino Pavasaris is the city's largest film festival.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-97)^ The Lithuanian Film Centre ([Lithuanian](/wiki/Lithuanian_language "Lithuanian language"): *Lietuvos kino centras* ), tasked with promoting the development and competitiveness of the Lithuanian film industry, is in Vilnius.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-98)^{#cite_ref-98}  

### Music {#Music}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Music")\]  
See also: [Music of Lithuania](/wiki/Music_of_Lithuania "Music of Lithuania")
[![Title page of a libretto](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Libretto_of_the_first_opera_staged_in_Vilnius_%281636%29.jpg/150px-Libretto_of_the_first_opera_staged_in_Vilnius_%281636%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Libretto_of_the_first_opera_staged_in_Vilnius_(1636).jpg) [Libretto](/wiki/Libretto "Libretto") of the first opera staged in Vilnius (1636), before the first operas in [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") (1645) and [London](/wiki/London "London") (1656)^[\[99\]](#cite_note-99)^

Musicians performed at the Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania as early as the 14th century, since Grand Duke Gediminas' daughter [Aldona of Lithuania](/wiki/Aldona_of_Lithuania "Aldona of Lithuania") was known to be enthusiastic about music. Aldona brought court musicians and singers to [Kraków](/wiki/Krak%C3%B3w "Kraków") after marrying King [Casimir III the Great](/wiki/Casimir_III_the_Great "Casimir III the Great").^[\[100\]](#cite_note-100)^ During the 16th century, composers such as [Wacław of Szamotuły](/wiki/Wac%C5%82aw_of_Szamotu%C5%82y "Wacław of Szamotuły"), [Jan Brant](/w/index.php?title=Jan_Brant&action=edit&redlink=1 "Jan Brant (page does not exist)"), [Heinrich Finck](/wiki/Heinrich_Finck "Heinrich Finck"), [Cyprian Bazylik](/wiki/Cyprian_Bazylik "Cyprian Bazylik"), [Alessandro Pesenti](/w/index.php?title=Alessandro_Pesenti&action=edit&redlink=1 "Alessandro Pesenti (page does not exist)"), [Luca Marenzio](/wiki/Luca_Marenzio "Luca Marenzio"), and [Michelagnolo Galilei](/wiki/Michelagnolo_Galilei "Michelagnolo Galilei") lived in Vilnius; the city was also home to [virtuoso](/wiki/Virtuoso "Virtuoso") [lutist](/wiki/Lute "Lute") [Bálint Bakfark](/wiki/B%C3%A1lint_Bakfark "Bálint Bakfark"). One of the first local musicians in written sources was Steponas Vilnietis (Stephanus de Vylna). The first textbook of Lithuanian music, *The Art and Practice of Music* ([Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language"): *Ars et praxis musica* ), was published in Vilnius by [Žygimantas Liauksminas](/wiki/%C5%BDygimantas_Liauksminas "Žygimantas Liauksminas") in 1667.^[\[101\]](#cite_note-101)^{#cite_ref-101}

Italian artists produced Lithuania's first [opera](/wiki/Opera "Opera") on 4 September 1636 at the Palace of the Grand Dukes, commissioned by Grand Duke [Władysław IV Vasa](/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_IV_Vasa "Władysław IV Vasa").^[\[102\]](#cite_note-102)^ Operas are produced at the [Lithuanian National Opera and Ballet Theatre](/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Opera_and_Ballet_Theatre "Lithuanian National Opera and Ballet Theatre") and by the [Vilnius City Opera](/wiki/Vilnius_City_Opera "Vilnius City Opera").^[\[103\]](#cite_note-103)^{#cite_ref-103}

The Lithuanian National Philharmonic Society, the country's largest and oldest state-owned concert organization, produces live concerts and tours in Lithuania and abroad.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-104)^ The [Lithuanian State Symphony Orchestra](/wiki/Lithuanian_State_Symphony_Orchestra "Lithuanian State Symphony Orchestra"), founded by [Gintaras Rinkevičius](/wiki/Gintaras_Rinkevi%C4%8Dius "Gintaras Rinkevičius"), performs in Vilnius.^[\[105\]](#cite_note-105)^{#cite_ref-105}
[![An outdoor stage and a crowd](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg/220px-Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dainu_svente_2009-07-06.jpg) The Lithuanian Song and Dance Festival in Vingis Park

[Choral music](/wiki/Choral_music "Choral music") is popular in Lithuania, and Vilnius has three choir laureates (Brevis, Jauna Muzika, and the Chamber Choir of the Conservatoire) at the [European Grand Prix for Choral Singing](/wiki/European_Grand_Prix_for_Choral_Singing "European Grand Prix for Choral Singing").^[\[106\]](#cite_note-106)^ The [Lithuanian Song and Dance Festival](/wiki/Lithuanian_Song_and_Dance_Festival "Lithuanian Song and Dance Festival") in Vilnius has been presented every four years since 1990 for about 30,000 singers and folk dancers in [Vingis Park](/wiki/Vingis_Park "Vingis Park").^[\[107\]](#cite_note-107)^ In 2008, the festival and its [Latvian](/wiki/Latvian_Song_and_Dance_Festival "Latvian Song and Dance Festival") and [Estonian](/wiki/Estonian_Song_Festival "Estonian Song Festival") counterparts were designated as a [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") [Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity](/wiki/Masterpieces_of_the_Oral_and_Intangible_Heritage_of_Humanity "Masterpieces of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity").^[\[108\]](#cite_note-108)^{#cite_ref-108}

The [jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") scene is active in Vilnius; in 1970--71, the Ganelin/Tarasov/Chekasin trio founded the Vilnius Jazz School.^[\[109\]](#cite_note-109)^ The [Vilnius Jazz Festival](/wiki/Vilnius_Jazz_Festival "Vilnius Jazz Festival") is held annually.{#cite_ref-109}
[![A middle-aged man in a leather jacket and jeans](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Andrius_Mamontovas_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg/220px-Andrius_Mamontovas_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg)](/wiki/File:Andrius_Mamontovas_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg) [Andrius Mamontovas](/wiki/Andrius_Mamontovas "Andrius Mamontovas"), leader of [Foje](/wiki/Foje "Foje") and founder of the annual *Gatvės muzikos diena* (Street Music Day)

The annual *Gatvės muzikos diena* (Street Music Day) gathers musicians on the city's streets.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-110)^ Vilnius is the birthplace of singers [Mariana Korvelytė -- Moravskienė](/w/index.php?title=Mariana_Korvelyt%C4%97_%E2%80%93_Moravskien%C4%97&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mariana Korvelytė – Moravskienė (page does not exist)"), [Paulina Rivoli](/wiki/Paulina_Rivoli "Paulina Rivoli"), [Danielius Dolskis](/wiki/Danielius_Dolskis "Danielius Dolskis"), [Vytautas Kernagis](/wiki/Vytautas_Kernagis "Vytautas Kernagis"), [Algirdas Kaušpėdas](/wiki/Algirdas_Kau%C5%A1p%C4%97das "Algirdas Kaušpėdas"), [Andrius Mamontovas](/wiki/Andrius_Mamontovas "Andrius Mamontovas"), [Nomeda Kazlaus](/wiki/Nomeda_Kazlaus "Nomeda Kazlaus"), and [Asmik Grigorian](/wiki/Asmik_Grigorian "Asmik Grigorian")); composers [César Cui](/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Cui "César Cui"), [Felix Yaniewicz](/wiki/Felix_Yaniewicz "Felix Yaniewicz"), [Maximilian Steinberg](/wiki/Maximilian_Steinberg "Maximilian Steinberg"), [Vytautas Miškinis](/wiki/Vytautas_Mi%C5%A1kinis "Vytautas Miškinis"), and [Onutė Narbutaitė](/wiki/Onut%C4%97_Narbutait%C4%97 "Onutė Narbutaitė")); conductor [Mirga Gražinytė-Tyla](/wiki/Mirga_Gra%C5%BEinyt%C4%97-Tyla "Mirga Gražinytė-Tyla")), and musicians [Antoni Radziwiłł](/wiki/Antoni_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82 "Antoni Radziwiłł"), [Jascha Heifetz](/wiki/Jascha_Heifetz "Jascha Heifetz"), [Clara Rockmore](/wiki/Clara_Rockmore "Clara Rockmore"), and [Romas Lileikis](/wiki/Romas_Lileikis "Romas Lileikis")).{#cite_ref-110}

It was the hometown of 18th-century composers [Michał Kazimierz Ogiński](/wiki/Micha%C5%82_Kazimierz_Ogi%C5%84ski "Michał Kazimierz Ogiński"), [Johann David Holland](/w/index.php?title=Johann_David_Holland&action=edit&redlink=1 "Johann David Holland (page does not exist)") (colleague of [C. Bach](/wiki/Carl_Philipp_Emanuel_Bach "Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach")), [Maciej Radziwiłł](/wiki/Maciej_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82 "Maciej Radziwiłł"), and [Michał Kleofas Ogiński](/wiki/Micha%C5%82_Kleofas_Ogi%C5%84ski "Michał Kleofas Ogiński"). Nineteenth-century Vilnius was known for singer [Kristina Gerhardi Frank](/w/index.php?title=Kristina_Gerhardi_Frank&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kristina Gerhardi Frank (page does not exist)"), a close friend of [Mozart](/wiki/Wolfgang_Amadeus_Mozart "Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart") and [Haydn](/wiki/Joseph_Haydn "Joseph Haydn") (who starred in the [premiere](/wiki/Premiere "Premiere") of Haydn's *[Creation](/wiki/The_Creation_(Haydn) "The Creation (Haydn)")* ), mid-19th century guitar virtuoso [Marek Konrad Sokołowski](/w/index.php?title=Marek_Konrad_Soko%C5%82owski&action=edit&redlink=1 "Marek Konrad Sokołowski (page does not exist)") and composer [Stanisław Moniuszko](/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Moniuszko "Stanisław Moniuszko"). The wealthiest woman in Vilnius during the early 19th century was singer [Maria de Neri](/w/index.php?title=Maria_de_Neri&action=edit&redlink=1 "Maria de Neri (page does not exist)"). In the early 20th century, Vilnius was the hometown of [Mikalojus Konstantinas Čiurlionis](/wiki/Mikalojus_Konstantinas_%C4%8Ciurlionis "Mikalojus Konstantinas Čiurlionis"), [Mikas Petrauskas](/wiki/Mikas_Petrauskas "Mikas Petrauskas"), and [Juozas Tallat-Kelpša](/wiki/Juozas_Tallat-Kelp%C5%A1a "Juozas Tallat-Kelpša"). Late-20th- and early 21st-century musicians include [Vyacheslav Ganelin](/wiki/Vyacheslav_Ganelin "Vyacheslav Ganelin"), [Petras Vyšniauskas](/wiki/Petras_Vy%C5%A1niauskas "Petras Vyšniauskas"), [Petras Geniušas](/wiki/Petras_Geniu%C5%A1as "Petras Geniušas"), [Mūza Rubackytė](/wiki/M%C5%ABza_Rubackyt%C4%97 "Mūza Rubackytė"), [Alanas Chošnau](/wiki/Alanas_Cho%C5%A1nau "Alanas Chošnau"), and [Marijonas Mikutavičius](/wiki/Marijonas_Mikutavi%C4%8Dius "Marijonas Mikutavičius").

The [Lithuanian Academy of Music and Theatre](/wiki/Lithuanian_Academy_of_Music_and_Theatre "Lithuanian Academy of Music and Theatre"), headquartered on [Gediminas Avenue](/wiki/Gediminas_Avenue "Gediminas Avenue"), is also located at the [Slushko Palace](/wiki/Slushko_Palace "Slushko Palace") in [Antakalnis](/wiki/Antakalnis "Antakalnis"). Singers who have lectured at the academy include [tenors](/wiki/Tenor "Tenor") [Kipras Petrauskas](/wiki/Kipras_Petrauskas "Kipras Petrauskas") and [Virgilijus Noreika](/wiki/Virgilijus_Noreika "Virgilijus Noreika").^[\[111\]](#cite_note-111)^{#cite_ref-111}  

### Theatre {#Theatre}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Theatre")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/The_History_of_Lithuanian_Theater._Theatre_programme_in_Latin_of_the_play_Algirdas_-_Magnus_Dux_of_Lithuania%2C_1687.jpg/150px-The_History_of_Lithuanian_Theater._Theatre_programme_in_Latin_of_the_play_Algirdas_-_Magnus_Dux_of_Lithuania%2C_1687.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_History_of_Lithuanian_Theater._Theatre_programme_in_Latin_of_the_play_Algirdas_-_Magnus_Dux_of_Lithuania,_1687.jpg) 1687 [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin") page of a theatre program dedicated to [Algirdas](/wiki/Algirdas "Algirdas"), which was performed in Vilnius

The Lithuanian Grand Dukes' entertainment at the castle, rulers' visits abroad and guests' meetings had theatrical elements. During [Sigismund III Vasa](/wiki/Sigismund_III_Vasa "Sigismund III Vasa")'s residence in Vilnius in the early 17th century, English actors performed at the palace. Władysław IV Vasa established a professional opera theatre in the Lower Castle in 1635, where *[drammas per musica](/wiki/Dramma_per_musica "Dramma per musica")* were performed by the Italian Virgilio Puccitelli. The performances had basic, luxurious scenography.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-112)^{#cite_ref-112}

A Jesuit School Theatre existed between the 16th and 18th centuries, with its first performance (*Hercules* by S. Tucci) in 1570 in Vilnius. Baroque aesthetics prevailed at the theatre, which also had [medieval](/wiki/Middle_Ages "Middle Ages") retrospectives, Renaissance elements, [Rococo](/wiki/Rococo "Rococo") motifs, and an educational function. Performances were in Latin, but elements of the Lithuanian language were included and some of the works had Lithuanian themes ([plays](/wiki/Play_(theatre) "Play (theatre)") dedicated to [Algirdas](/wiki/Algirdas "Algirdas"), Mindaugas, Vytautas and other Lithuanian rulers).^[\[113\]](#cite_note-113)^^[\[114\]](#cite_note-theatrevle-114)^{#cite_ref-theatrevle_114-0}

[Wojciech Bogusławski](/wiki/Wojciech_Bogus%C5%82awski "Wojciech Bogusławski") established Vilnius City Theatre, the city's first public theatre, in 1785. The theatre, initially in the Oskierka Palace, moved to the [Radziwiłł Palace](/wiki/Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82_Palace,_Vilnius "Radziwiłł Palace, Vilnius") and [Vilnius Town Hall](/wiki/Town_Hall,_Vilnius "Town Hall, Vilnius"). Plays were performed in Polish until 1845, from 1845 to 1864 in Polish and Russian, and after 1864 in Russian. After the Lithuanian-language ban was lifted, plays were also performed in Lithuanian. The theatre closed in 1914.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-115)^{#cite_ref-115}
[![Exterior of a large, white building](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre_in_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_in_2023.jpg/220px-Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre_in_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_in_2023.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre_in_Vilnius,_Lithuania_in_2023.jpg) The [Lithuanian National Drama Theatre](/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre "Lithuanian National Drama Theatre")

During the interwar period (when the city was part of Poland), Vilnius was known for the modern, experimental Reduta troupe and institute led by [Juliusz Osterwa](/wiki/Juliusz_Osterwa "Juliusz Osterwa").^[\[116\]](#cite_note-116)^ The Vilnius Lithuanian Stage Amateur Company (Lithuanian: *Vilniaus lietuvių scenos mėgėjų kuopa* ), established in 1930 and renamed Vilnius's Lithuanian Theatre, performed in the region. In 1945, it was merged with the [Lithuanian National Drama Theatre](/wiki/Lithuanian_National_Drama_Theatre "Lithuanian National Drama Theatre").^[\[114\]](#cite_note-theatrevle-114)^{#cite_ref-theatrevle_114-1}

After the Soviet occupation of Lithuania in 1940, theatre became a means of disseminating Soviet ideology. Performances incorporated socialist realism, and a number of [revolutionary](/wiki/Russian_Revolution "Russian Revolution") plays by Russian authors were staged. A Repertory Commission was established under the Ministry of Culture to direct theatres, control repertoire, and permit (or ban) performances.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-theatrevle-114)^{#cite_ref-theatrevle_114-2}

Theatre changed after Lithuanian independence.^[\[114\]](#cite_note-theatrevle-114)^ The independent Vilnius City Opera blends classical and contemporary art. The Lithuanian National Drama Theatre, State Small Theatre of Vilnius, State Youth Theatre and a number of private theatre companies (including OKT/Vilnius City Theatre and the Anželika Cholina Dance Theatre) present classical, modern and Lithuanian plays directed by noted Lithuanian and foreign directors. There is also a Russian-language [Old Theatre of Vilnius](/wiki/Old_Theatre_of_Vilnius "Old Theatre of Vilnius").^[\[117\]](#cite_note-117)^{#cite_ref-117}  

### Photography {#Photography}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Photography")\]
[![Very old photo of a solar flare](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Coronal_mass_ejection%2C_captured_in_1867_with_Vilnius_photoheliograph.jpg/150px-Coronal_mass_ejection%2C_captured_in_1867_with_Vilnius_photoheliograph.jpg)](/wiki/File:Coronal_mass_ejection,_captured_in_1867_with_Vilnius_photoheliograph.jpg) A [coronal mass ejection](/wiki/Coronal_mass_ejection "Coronal mass ejection"), captured in 1867 with Vilnius' [photoheliograph](/wiki/Photoheliograph "Photoheliograph") (the second such device in the world)

According to the memoirs of architect Bolesław Podczaszyński, published in January 1853 in the *[Gazeta Warszawska](/wiki/Gazeta_Warszawska "Gazeta Warszawska")*, Lithuanian [photography](/wiki/Photography "Photography") began with the [daguerreotyping](/wiki/Daguerreotype "Daguerreotype") in the summer of 1839 of the reconstructed [Verkiai Palace](/wiki/Verkiai_Palace "Verkiai Palace") by François Marcillac (governor of the children of Duke [Ludwig Wittgenstein](/wiki/Ludwig_zu_Sayn-Wittgenstein-Berleburg "Ludwig zu Sayn-Wittgenstein-Berleburg")).^[\[118\]](#cite_note-photovle-118)^ The country's unfavorable political situation hampered the development of new technology and cultural activities. The first known daguerreotype-portrait [atelier](/wiki/Atelier "Atelier") in Vilnius was opened in 1843 by C. Ziegler, and ateliers operated in Lithuania until 1859. One of the best-known photographers was K. Neupert, from [Norway](/wiki/Norway "Norway").^[\[118\]](#cite_note-photovle-118)^{#cite_ref-photovle_118-1}

In the 1860s, with the spread of the [collodion process](/wiki/Collodion_process "Collodion process"), [glass negatives](/wiki/Photographic_plate "Photographic plate") and [albumen paper](/wiki/Albumen_paper "Albumen paper") were used instead of daguerreotype plates. Photo portraits in standard formats became widespread, and commercial photography ateliers were established in Vilnius and other Lithuanian cities. The first landscape and architectural photographs were made by Vilnius photographers [Abdonas Korzonas](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abdonas_Korzonas "lt:Abdonas Korzonas") and Albert Swieykowski, who compiled the 32-image *Vilnius Album* (Lithuania's first set of photographs). In 1862, Provisional Censorship Regulations governing the activities of photographic institutions were adopted in 1862, supervised by the Central Press Board of the Ministry of the Interior. Those who photographed the rebels in the [January Uprising](/wiki/January_Uprising "January Uprising") were punished; A. Korzonas was deported to [Siberia](/wiki/Siberia "Siberia"). Other prominent 19th-century photographers were [Stanisław Filibert Fleury](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanislovas_Filibertas_Fleris "lt:Stanislovas Filibertas Fleris") (a [stereoscopic](/wiki/Stereoscopy "Stereoscopy")-photography pioneer),^[\[119\]](#cite_note-119)^ Aleksander Władysław Strauss, and [Józef Czechowicz](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juzefas_%C4%8Cechavi%C4%8Dius "lt:Juzefas Čechavičius").^[\[118\]](#cite_note-photovle-118)^{#cite_ref-photovle_118-2}

The world's second [photoheliograph](/wiki/Solar_telescope "Solar telescope") was installed in 1865 at the [Vilnius University Astronomical Observatory](/wiki/Vilnius_University_Astronomical_Observatory "Vilnius University Astronomical Observatory"), and photographed [sunspots](/wiki/Sunspot "Sunspot").^[\[118\]](#cite_note-photovle-118)^ An unprecedented system of photographing solar dynamics began in 1868 in Vilnius.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-Klimka-120)^ [Jan Bułhak](/wiki/Jan_Bu%C5%82hak "Jan Bułhak") founded the country's first photography club in Vilnius in 1927.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-121)^ In 1952, *Švyturys* magazine organized the city's first photography exhibition.^[\[118\]](#cite_note-photovle-118)^{#cite_ref-photovle_118-4}  

### Crafts {#Crafts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Crafts")\]  
[![An ornate gold monstrance](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Did%C5%BEioji_monstrancija.tif/lossy-page1-136px-Did%C5%BEioji_monstrancija.tif.jpg)](/wiki/File:Did%C5%BEioji_monstrancija.tif)  
The Great [Monstrance](/wiki/Monstrance "Monstrance"), commissioned in Vilnius in 1535 by [Albertas Goštautas](/wiki/Albertas_Go%C5%A1tautas "Albertas Goštautas"), is one of [central Europe](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe")'s largest.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-122)^  
[![Detailed reverse of a gold coin](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Lithuania_1616_10_Ducats_%28reverse%29.jpg/198px-Lithuania_1616_10_Ducats_%28reverse%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lithuania_1616_10_Ducats_(reverse).jpg)  
Reverse of [Sigismund III Vasa](/wiki/Sigismund_III_Vasa "Sigismund III Vasa")'s 10-[ducat](/wiki/Ducat "Ducat") gold coin, struck in the [Vilnius Mint](/wiki/Vilnius_Mint "Vilnius Mint") in 1616, with the [coat of arms of the Polish--Lithuanian Commonwealth](/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_the_Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth "Coat of arms of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth") and the [privy marks](/wiki/Privy_mark "Privy mark") of [Podskarbi wielki litewski](/wiki/Podskarbi "Podskarbi") [Hieronim Wołłowicz](/wiki/Hieronim_Wo%C5%82%C5%82owicz "Hieronim Wołłowicz")

Iron tools, weapons, [brass](/wiki/Brass "Brass"), [glass](/wiki/Glass "Glass") and [silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver") jewelry have been produced in present-day Lithuania since the first century.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-amatai-123)^ [Pottery](/wiki/Pottery "Pottery") wood products, and [weaving](/wiki/Weaving "Weaving") became widespread in the second and fourth centuries. During the [feudal](/wiki/Feudalism "Feudalism") era, home [crafts](/wiki/Crafts "Crafts") were components of a [subsistence economy](/wiki/Subsistence_economy "Subsistence economy"). During the 13th and 14th centuries, crafts became a branch of the economy separate from agriculture. The Grand Dukes of Lithuania promoted the development of crafts in cities, and weaving, shoemaking, fur-making and other crafts predominated. With the early-14th-century introduction of foreign artisans, the development of crafts accelerated; crafts and trade stimulated the growth of Vilnius and other Lithuanian cities. In the 14th and 15th centuries, crafts were specialized (especially the production of tools, household items, fabrics, clothing, weapons, and jewelry); [workshops](/wiki/Workshop "Workshop") were established which trained and defended the interests of craftspeople. Production of fine [glassware](/wiki/Glassware "Glassware") began, [goldsmithing](/wiki/Goldsmithing "Goldsmithing") was developed, and the level of pottery and weaving rose during the 16th century, and the 1529 and 1588 Statutes of Lithuania identify 25 crafts.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-amatai-123)^ European goldsmiths worked in the [Vilnius Goldsmiths' Workshop](/wiki/Vilnius_Goldsmiths%27_Workshop "Vilnius Goldsmiths' Workshop") (established in 1495), which controlled trade in [precious metals](/wiki/Precious_metal "Precious metal") and [gemstones](/wiki/Gemstone "Gemstone") and served the [Daugava](/wiki/Daugava "Daugava") and [Dnieper](/wiki/Dnieper "Dnieper") regions, the [Catholic Church](/wiki/Catholic_Church_in_Lithuania "Catholic Church in Lithuania"), the Grand Duke, the [nobility](/wiki/Szlachta "Szlachta"), and townspeople.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-124)^ The [Vilnius Mint](/wiki/Vilnius_Mint "Vilnius Mint"), the main [mint](/wiki/Mint_(facility) "Mint (facility)") of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, minted the Lithuanian [denarius](/wiki/Denarius "Denarius"), [shillings](/wiki/Shilling "Shilling"), [groschen](/wiki/Groschen "Groschen"), [thalers](/wiki/Thaler "Thaler"), [ducats](/wiki/Ducat "Ducat"), and other coins from 1387 to 1666.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-125)^{#cite_ref-125}

Crafting declined in the second half of the 17th century due to the [Russo-Polish War](/wiki/Russo-Polish_War_(1654%E2%80%931667) "Russo-Polish War (1654–1667)"), and most goods were imported and sold by Lithuanian and Polish nobles. It revived from the second half of the 18th century to the first half of the 19th century, with Vilnius the largest Lithuanian craft center. After the abolition of [serfdom](/wiki/Serfdom "Serfdom"), craft schools were established in Lithuanian cities; crafts have prevailed in [clothing](/wiki/Clothing "Clothing") manufacturing, goldsmithing, woodworking, food processing, and other fields. Under Soviet occupation, craftspeople worked in [artels](/wiki/Artel "Artel") until 1960 and then in [combines](/wiki/Combine_(enterprise) "Combine (enterprise)"). After independence, crafts were produced by small and medium-sized businesses.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-amatai-123)^{#cite_ref-amatai_123-2}  

### Language {#Language}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Language")\]  
See also: [Demographic history of Vilnius § Historic ethnic makeup](/wiki/Demographic_history_of_Vilnius#Historic_ethnic_makeup "Demographic history of Vilnius"), and [Lithuanian language](/wiki/Lithuanian_language "Lithuanian language")
[![An old manuscript](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Edict_of_Vytautas_the_Great._Issued_1410-_02-16.jpg/220px-Edict_of_Vytautas_the_Great._Issued_1410-_02-16.jpg)](/wiki/File:Edict_of_Vytautas_the_Great._Issued_1410-_02-16.jpg) Edict issued by Vytautas the Great in Vilnius on 16 February 1410 in [Latin](/wiki/Latin "Latin")  
[![Title page of an old book](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Lithuanian_primer_for_kids%2C_published_in_Vilnius%2C_Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania%2C_1783_edition.jpg/103px-Lithuanian_primer_for_kids%2C_published_in_Vilnius%2C_Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania%2C_1783_edition.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lithuanian_primer_for_kids,_published_in_Vilnius,_Grand_Duchy_of_Lithuania,_1783_edition.jpg)  
1783 [Lithuanian language primer](/wiki/Mokslas_skaitymo_ra%C5%A1to_lietuvi%C5%A1ko "Mokslas skaitymo rašto lietuviško"), published in Vilnius  
[![An old manuscript](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Constitution_of_May_3_in_Lithuanian_language.jpg/111px-Constitution_of_May_3_in_Lithuanian_language.jpg)](/wiki/File:Constitution_of_May_3_in_Lithuanian_language.jpg)  
Manuscript of the [Constitution of 3 May 1791](/wiki/Constitution_of_3_May_1791 "Constitution of 3 May 1791") in Lithuanian^[\[126\]](#cite_note-Old_Lithuanian_texts-126)^

A [multicultural](/wiki/Multiculturalism "Multiculturalism") city, Vilnius' language changed over the centuries. The predominant spoken language in [medieval](/wiki/Medieval "Medieval") Lithuania was Lithuanian. It had no literary tradition, however, and was not used in writing except for religious texts such as the [Lord's Prayer](/wiki/Lord%27s_Prayer "Lord's Prayer") and the [Hail Mary](/wiki/Hail_Mary "Hail Mary").^[\[127\]](#cite_note-kalbos-127)^^[\[88\]](#cite_note-Dubonis2002-88)^ [Vytautas](/wiki/Vytautas "Vytautas") the Great spoke in Lithuanian with [Jogaila](/wiki/W%C5%82adys%C5%82aw_II_Jagie%C5%82%C5%82o "Władysław II Jagiełło"), whose son [Casimir IV Jagiellon](/wiki/Casimir_IV_Jagiellon "Casimir IV Jagiellon") also spoke Lithuanian.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-128)^^[\[129\]](#cite_note-129)^^[\[130\]](#cite_note-130)^ [Saint Casimir](/wiki/Saint_Casimir "Saint Casimir"), the patron saint of Lithuania, knew Lithuanian, Polish, German and Latin.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-VilniusCathedral-131)^ Fifteenth-century [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire") historian [Laonikos Chalkokondyles](/wiki/Laonikos_Chalkokondyles "Laonikos Chalkokondyles") reported that the Lithuanians had a distinct language.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-132)^^\[*[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")*\]^{#cite_ref-132}

[Ruthenian](/wiki/Ruthenian_language "Ruthenian language") was used after the incorporation of [Kievan Rus'](/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27 "Kievan Rus'"), forming the basis of 19th-century Ukrainian and [Belarusian](/wiki/Belarusian_language "Belarusian language"). Written Ruthenian stemmed from the interaction of [Old East Slavic](/wiki/Old_East_Slavic "Old East Slavic") with Ruthenian dialects, becoming the main language of the [chancery](/wiki/Chancery_(medieval_office) "Chancery (medieval office)") of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania in the 14th and 15th centuries and maintained its dominance until the mid-17th century.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-kalbos-127)^^[\[133\]](#cite_note-133)^{#cite_ref-133}

Latin and [Polish](/wiki/Polish_language "Polish language") were also widely used in the chancery; Polish replaced Ruthenian in written sources and Lithuanian in public use during the second half of the 17th century. The first state documents in Lithuanian appeared in the Grand Duchy of Lithuania at the end of its existence.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-kalbos-127)^{#cite_ref-kalbos_127-2}

At the Vilnius court of [Sigismund II Augustus](/wiki/Sigismund_II_Augustus "Sigismund II Augustus"), the last Grand Duke of Lithuania before the [Union of Lublin](/wiki/Union_of_Lublin "Union of Lublin"), Polish and Lithuanian were spoken.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-134)^ In 1552, Sigismund ordered that orders from the Magistrate of Vilnius be announced in Lithuanian, Polish, and Ruthenian.^[\[135\]](#cite_note-135)^ Minorities such as [Jews](/wiki/Litvaks "Litvaks"), [Lipka Tatars](/wiki/Lipka_Tatars "Lipka Tatars"), and [Crimean Karaites](/wiki/Crimean_Karaites "Crimean Karaites") were ruled by the Grand Duke of Lithuania, and their languages were only used among themselves.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-136)^ According to Article 14 of the Lithuanian constitution, Lithuanian is the [official language](/wiki/Official_language "Official language"); however, [interpreter](/wiki/Interpreter "Interpreter") assistance is sometimes provided.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-137)^{#cite_ref-137}  

### Fashion {#Fashion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Fashion")\]  
[![Painting of a man, standing](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Janusz_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82_by_Daniel_Schultz.PNG/130px-Janusz_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82_by_Daniel_Schultz.PNG)](/wiki/File:Janusz_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82_by_Daniel_Schultz.PNG)  
[![Painting of a smiling woman in masculine clothing](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Emerencyjana_Paciej_%28Warszycka%29._%D0%AD%D0%BC%D1%8D%D1%80%D1%8D%D0%BD%D1%86%D1%8B%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B5%D0%B9_%28%D0%92%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D1%8B%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F%29_%28%C3%81._M%C3%A1nyoki%2C_1718%29.jpg/180px-Emerencyjana_Paciej_%28Warszycka%29._%D0%AD%D0%BC%D1%8D%D1%80%D1%8D%D0%BD%D1%86%D1%8B%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B5%D0%B9_%28%D0%92%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D1%8B%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F%29_%28%C3%81._M%C3%A1nyoki%2C_1718%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Emerencyjana_Paciej_(Warszycka)._%D0%AD%D0%BC%D1%8D%D1%80%D1%8D%D0%BD%D1%86%D1%8B%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%9F%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B5%D0%B9_(%D0%92%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%88%D1%8B%D1%86%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F)_(%C3%81._M%C3%A1nyoki,_1718).jpg)  
[Janusz Radziwiłł](/wiki/Janusz_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82_(1612%E2%80%931655) "Janusz Radziwiłł (1612–1655)") *(left)* , wearing a żupan and kontush belt; Emerencjanna Pociej, wife of [Ludwik Pociej](/wiki/Ludwik_Pociej "Ludwik Pociej"), in Western European clothing

According to historian [Antanas Čaplinskas](/wiki/Antanas_%C4%8Caplinskas "Antanas Čaplinskas"), wives of merchants and craftsmen wore rings decorated with gemstones. Sixteenth- and seventeenth-century property inventories list long, wide-sleeved jackets (known as [kontusz](/wiki/Kontusz "Kontusz")), [żupans](/wiki/%C5%BBupan "Żupan") decorated with fur, and [kontush belts](/wiki/Pas_kontuszowy "Pas kontuszowy").^[\[138\]](#cite_note-clothing-138)^ [Buttons](/wiki/Button "Button"), made of [pearl](/wiki/Pearl "Pearl"), [coral](/wiki/Coral "Coral"), [brilliant-cut diamonds](/wiki/Brilliant_(diamond_cut) "Brilliant (diamond cut)") and [emeralds](/wiki/Emerald "Emerald"), were decorated with diamonds and enamel.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-clothing-138)^ [Delias](/wiki/Delia_(clothing) "Delia (clothing)") and [dolmans](/wiki/Dolman "Dolman") were popular with townspeople and nobles.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-ragauskas-139)^{#cite_ref-ragauskas_139-0}

Wealthy townspeople in luxurious clothing aroused the envy of Lithuanian nobility, who demanded laws regulating attire. The 1588 Statute of Lithuania limited townspeople to two rings, and Jews could not wear gold chains and [brooches](/wiki/Brooch "Brooch").^[\[138\]](#cite_note-clothing-138)^ Broader restrictions were imposed by the [Sejm of the Polish--Lithuanian Commonwealth](/wiki/Sejm_of_the_Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth "Sejm of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth"), which adopted the 1613 Act of Thrift forbidding non-noble townspeople from wearing expensive furs in public.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-clothing-138)^ Payment of a fee later removed the limitations.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-clothing-138)^{#cite_ref-clothing_138-4}

During the late 18th century, almost all men shaved; their hair was short, and they wore open-front blue, green or black [tailcoats](/wiki/Tailcoat "Tailcoat") and [waistcoats](/wiki/Waistcoat "Waistcoat") with white or light-yellow trousers;^[\[139\]](#cite_note-ragauskas-139)^ women's clothing echoed West European styles. In the early 20th century, clothing followed West European fashion trends. The [State Art Institute of Lithuania](/wiki/State_Art_Institute_of_Lithuania "State Art Institute of Lithuania") introduced clothing-design studies, and the Vilnius Model House (popularizing apparel and footwear) was established in 1961.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-140)^{#cite_ref-140}

The annual Vilnius spring *Mados infekcija* (Fashion Infection), Lithuania's largest [fashion show](/wiki/Fashion_show "Fashion show"), began in 1999.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-141)^ Lithuanian clothing designer [Juozas Statkevičius](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juozas_Statkevi%C4%8Dius "lt:Juozas Statkevičius") usually presents his shows in the city.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-142)^{#cite_ref-142}  

### Holidays and festivals {#Holidays_and_festivals}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Holidays and festivals")\]
[![A crowded street scene](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Kaziuko_muge_2010.jpg/220px-Kaziuko_muge_2010.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kaziuko_muge_2010.jpg) Kaziuko mugė is held each March to honor Saint Casimir

Catholic holidays such as [Christmas](/wiki/Christmas "Christmas"), [Easter](/wiki/Easter "Easter"), and [Saint John's Eve](/wiki/Saint_John%27s_Eve "Saint John's Eve")) are widely celebrated.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-143)^ On 16 February (anniversary of the Act of Independence of Lithuania) and 11 March (anniversary of the [Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania](/wiki/Act_of_the_Re-Establishment_of_the_State_of_Lithuania "Act of the Re-Establishment of the State of Lithuania")), festive and religious events take place in Vilnius.^[\[144\]](#cite_note-144)^^[\[145\]](#cite_note-145)^ On the evening of 12 January, bonfires are lit to commemorate the January Events.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-146)^{#cite_ref-146}

[Kaziuko mugė](/wiki/Kaziuko_mug%C4%97 "Kaziuko mugė") (Saint Casimir's Fair), held annually in the city's markets and streets on the Sunday nearest to 4 March (the feast of [Saint Casimir](/wiki/Saint_Casimir "Saint Casimir")), attracts many visitors and Lithuanian and foreign craftspeople. [Easter palms](/wiki/Easter_palm "Easter palm") (Lithuanian: *Verbos* ) are symbolic of the fair.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-147)^ Capital Days (Lithuanian: *Sostinės dienos* ), Vilnius' largest festival of music and culture, is held from 30 August to 1 September.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-148)^ The river Vilnia is dyed green every year for [Saint Patrick's Day](/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_Day "Saint Patrick's Day").^[\[149\]](#cite_note-149)^ During the annual [Vilnius Culture Night](/wiki/Vilnius_Culture_Night "Vilnius Culture Night"), artists and cultural organisations hold events and performances throughout the city.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-Kulturos_Naktos-150)^{#cite_ref-Kulturos_Naktos_150-0}  

Administration {#Administration}
--------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Administration")\]  

### Government {#City_government}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Government")\]  
See also: [Voivode of Vilnius](/wiki/Voivode_of_Vilnius "Voivode of Vilnius") and [Mayor of Vilnius](/wiki/Mayor_of_Vilnius "Mayor of Vilnius")
[![Painting of an older, bearded man](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/Krzysztof_Miko%C5%82aj_%22the_Thunderbolt%22_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82_1.PNG/180px-Krzysztof_Miko%C5%82aj_%22the_Thunderbolt%22_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82_1.PNG)](/wiki/File:Krzysztof_Miko%C5%82aj_%22the_Thunderbolt%22_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82_1.PNG) [Krzysztof "Piorun" Radziwiłł](/wiki/Krzysztof_%22Piorun%22_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82 "Krzysztof \"Piorun\" Radziwiłł") was [Voivode of Vilnius](/wiki/Voivode_of_Vilnius "Voivode of Vilnius") from 1584 to 1603. After his victories against [Ivan the Terrible](/wiki/Ivan_the_Terrible "Ivan the Terrible") during the [Livonian War](/wiki/Livonian_War "Livonian War"), he was nicknamed "the Thunderbolt".

Before [Magdeburg rights](/wiki/Magdeburg_rights "Magdeburg rights") were granted to Vilnius in 1378, the city was ruled by [vicegerents](/wiki/Vicegerent "Vicegerent"). Government was later granted to a magistrate or a city council, subordinate to the ruler. In wartime, it was led by a [voivode](/wiki/Voivode_of_Vilnius "Voivode of Vilnius").^[\[151\]](#cite_note-government-151)^ The government headquarters was at Vilnius Town Hall.^[\[152\]](#cite_note-152)^{#cite_ref-152}

The magistrate was responsible for the city's economy: collecting taxes, overseeing the treasury, and accumulating stocks of grain to avoid starvation during famine or wars. He was a [notary](/wiki/Notary "Notary") in transactions and testaments, a [judge](/wiki/Judge "Judge") in conflicts involving construction and renovation, and took care of craftspeople; statutes involving workshops were approved by the ruler, but Sigismund II Augustus gave this responsibility to magistrates in 1552. Since a 1522 ruling by [Sigismund I the Old](/wiki/Sigismund_I_the_Old "Sigismund I the Old"), Vilnius magistrates had to protect the city and its residents with 24 armed guards. During wartime, the night watch was conducted by the magistrate, bishop and castle men.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-government-151)^^[\[153\]](#cite_note-153)^{#cite_ref-153}
[![Exterior of a large, white building, with a church in the background](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Rathaus%2BKasimir-Kirche.jpg/220px-Rathaus%2BKasimir-Kirche.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rathaus%2BKasimir-Kirche.jpg) The [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassicism "Neoclassicism") [Town Hall](/wiki/Town_Hall,_Vilnius "Town Hall, Vilnius"), designed by [Laurynas Gucevičius](/wiki/Laurynas_Gucevi%C4%8Dius "Laurynas Gucevičius") in 1799

The chief city administrator was a Catholic *vaitas* (a vicegerent of the Grand Duke of Lithuania),^[\[154\]](#cite_note-154)^ most of whom were beginning their careers in the magistracy, and chaired city-council meetings. He adjudicated [criminal cases](/wiki/Criminal_case "Criminal case"), with the right to impose capital punishment. Originally examining cases alone, two *suolininkai* also began examining important cases in the 16th century. At that time, the city council consisted of 12 [burgomasters](/wiki/Burgomaster "Burgomaster") and 24 councilors; half were Catholics, the other half [Orthodox](/wiki/Orthodoxy "Orthodoxy")). Members were chosen by wealthy townspeople, merchants, and workshop elders. Burgomasters were lifetime appointments; at death, another member of the council with the same religion was chosen. In 1536, Sigismund I the Old signed an edict prohibiting close relatives on the council and requiring prior agreement by the townspeople of new taxes, obligations and regulations.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-government-151)^{#cite_ref-government_151-2}
[![A large, modern building](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d5/Vilnius_City_Municipality_building.jpg/220px-Vilnius_City_Municipality_building.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_City_Municipality_building.jpg) The [Vilnius City Municipality Building](/wiki/Vilnius_City_Municipality_Building "Vilnius City Municipality Building") in [Konstitucijos Avenue](/wiki/Konstitucijos_Avenue "Konstitucijos Avenue"), which houses the city's municipal council and administration

Under the Russian Empire, the city council was replaced with a [city duma](/wiki/City_duma "City duma").^[\[155\]](#cite_note-LRistorija-155)^ Vilnius was the capital of the [Lithuania Governorate](/wiki/Lithuania_Governorate "Lithuania Governorate") from 1797 to 1801, the [Vilna Governorate-General](/wiki/Vilna_Governorate-General "Vilna Governorate-General") from 1794 to 1912, and the [Vilna Governorate](/wiki/Vilna_Governorate "Vilna Governorate") from 1795 to 1915.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-156)^^[\[157\]](#cite_note-157)^ After the [Soviet occupation of Lithuania](/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_Lithuania "Soviet occupation of Lithuania"), Vilnius was the capital of the [Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic](/wiki/Lithuanian_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic").^[\[155\]](#cite_note-LRistorija-155)^{#cite_ref-LRistorija_155-1}  

#### Vilnius City Municipality {#Vilnius_City_Municipality}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Vilnius City Municipality")\]

The Vilnius City Municipality is the representative self-government organ, one of 60 [municipalities of Lithuania](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Lithuania "Municipalities of Lithuania"). In addition to Vilnius proper, it includes the town of [Grigiškės](/wiki/Grigi%C5%A1k%C4%97s "Grigiškės"), as well as the villages and rural areas of the [Grigiškės eldership](/w/index.php?title=Grigi%C5%A1k%C4%97s_eldership&action=edit&redlink=1 "Grigiškės eldership (page does not exist)") \[[lt](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grigi%C5%A1ki%C5%B3_seni%C5%ABnija "lt:Grigiškių seniūnija")\].^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^

The [Vinius City Municipal Council](/w/index.php?title=Vinius_City_Municipal_Council&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vinius City Municipal Council (page does not exist)") \[[lt](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vilniaus_miesto_savivaldyb%C4%97s_taryba "lt:Vilniaus miesto savivaldybės taryba")\], established in 1990,^[\[155\]](#cite_note-LRistorija-155)^ is elected to four-year terms, and candidates are nominated by political parties and committees.^[\[158\]](#cite_note-Taryba-158)^ Beginning with the 2011 elections, independent candidates are permitted.^[\[159\]](#cite_note-159)^ Its executive organ is the [Vilnius City Municipality Administration](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius_City_Municipality_Administration&action=edit&redlink=1 "Vilnius City Municipality Administration (page does not exist)") \[[lt](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vilniaus_miesto_savivaldyb%C4%97s_administracija "lt:Vilniaus miesto savivaldybės administracija")\].{#cite_ref-159}

Before 2015, mayors were appointed by the council.^[\[160\]](#cite_note-TV3merai-160)^ Beginning that year, mayors were elected in a [two-round system](/wiki/Two-round_system "Two-round system").^[\[160\]](#cite_note-TV3merai-160)^ Remigijus Šimašius was the city's first directly elected mayor.^[\[161\]](#cite_note-161)^{#cite_ref-161}
