### Vilnius District Municipality {#Vilnius_District_Municipality}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Vilnius District Municipality")\]  
Further information: [Vilnius District Municipality](/wiki/Vilnius_District_Municipality "Vilnius District Municipality")
[![Aerial view of an old fortress](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Medinink%C5%B3_pilis_i%C5%A1_dangaus_-_www.aerialmedia.tv_02.jpg/220px-Medinink%C5%B3_pilis_i%C5%A1_dangaus_-_www.aerialmedia.tv_02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Medinink%C5%B3_pilis_i%C5%A1_dangaus_-_www.aerialmedia.tv_02.jpg) [Medininkai Castle](/wiki/Medininkai_Castle "Medininkai Castle"), built in the first half of the 14th century. It is the largest enclosure-type defensive [castle in Lithuania](/wiki/List_of_castles_in_Lithuania "List of castles in Lithuania") and a primary landmark in the district.^[\[164\]](#cite_note-164)^ [![See caption](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/VilniausRajonas.png/220px-VilniausRajonas.png)](/wiki/File:VilniausRajonas.png) Map of Vilnius district

Vilnius District Municipality (Lithuanian: *Vilniaus rajono savivaldybė* ), one of the country's largest municipalities, covers 2,129 square kilometres (822 sq mi) and has [23 elderships](/wiki/Vilnius_District_Municipality#Elderships "Vilnius District Municipality"). There are over 1,000 villages and five towns ([Nemenčinė](/wiki/Nemen%C4%8Din%C4%97 "Nemenčinė"), [Bezdonys](/wiki/Bezdonys "Bezdonys"), [Maišiagala](/wiki/Mai%C5%A1iagala "Maišiagala"), [Mickūnai](/wiki/Mick%C5%ABnai "Mickūnai") and [Šumskas](/wiki/%C5%A0umskas "Šumskas")) in the district. It borders [Belarus](/wiki/Belarus "Belarus") and the [Švenčionys](/wiki/%C5%A0ven%C4%8Dionys_district "Švenčionys district"), [Moletai](/wiki/Mol%C4%97tai_district "Molėtai district"), [Širvintos](/wiki/%C5%A0irvintos_district "Širvintos district"), [Elektrėnai](/wiki/Elektr%C4%97nai_district "Elektrėnai district"), [Trakai](/wiki/Trakai_district "Trakai district") and [Šalčininkai districts](/wiki/%C5%A0al%C4%8Dininkai_district "Šalčininkai district").^[\[165\]](#cite_note-district-165)^{#cite_ref-district_165-0}

The district has a multinational population, of which 52 percent are [Poles](/wiki/Poles_in_Lithuania "Poles in Lithuania"), 33 percent [Lithuanians](/wiki/Lithuanians "Lithuanians"), and the remainder [Russians](/wiki/Russians_in_Lithuania "Russians in Lithuania"), [Belarusians](/wiki/Belarusians_in_Lithuania "Belarusians in Lithuania") and other nationalities (including [Ukrainians](/wiki/Ukrainians_in_Lithuania "Ukrainians in Lithuania")). It has a population of over 100,000; 95 percent live in villages, and five percent live in towns.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-district-165)^ Vilnius district has Lithuania's highest terrain, with the [Aukštojas](/wiki/Auk%C5%A1tojas_Hill "Aukštojas Hill"), [Juozapinė](/wiki/Juozapin%C4%97_Hill "Juozapinė Hill") and [Kruopinė Hills](/wiki/Kruopin%C4%97_Hill "Kruopinė Hill") over 290 metres (950 ft) above [sea level](/wiki/Sea_level "Sea level").^[\[165\]](#cite_note-district-165)^{#cite_ref-district_165-2}

[Palm Sunday](/wiki/Palm_Sunday "Palm Sunday") is celebrated in the district, and Vilnian Easter palms (*verbos* ) are made from dried flowers and herbs.^[\[166\]](#cite_note-166)^ Palm-making dates to the time of St. Casimir.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-district-165)^{#cite_ref-district_165-3}

[Medininkai Castle](/wiki/Medininkai_Castle "Medininkai Castle"), the [Liubavas Manor](/wiki/Liubavas_Manor "Liubavas Manor") mill and Bareikiškės Manor are the district's best-known historic landmarks.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-district-165)^ From 1769 to 1795, [Vilnius Voivodeship](/wiki/Vilnius_Voivodeship "Vilnius Voivodeship") surrounded the independent [Republic of Paulava](/wiki/Republic_of_Paulava "Republic of Paulava"). The [microstate](/wiki/European_microstates "European microstates"), known for its [Enlightenment](/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment "Age of Enlightenment") values, had its own president, [peasant](/wiki/Peasant "Peasant") parliament, army and laws.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-167)^{#cite_ref-167}

With its large Polish population, the Vilnius District Municipality Council primarily consists of members of the [Electoral Action of Poles in Lithuania](/wiki/Electoral_Action_of_Poles_in_Lithuania "Electoral Action of Poles in Lithuania") party.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-168)^ Its mayor is [Robert Duchniewicz](/wiki/Robert_Duchniewicz "Robert Duchniewicz") of the [Lithuanian Social Democratic Union](/wiki/Lithuanian_Social_Democratic_Union "Lithuanian Social Democratic Union").^[\[169\]](#cite_note-169)^{#cite_ref-169}  

### National government {#National_government}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: National government")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/2c/Vilnius_Seimas.jpg/220px-Vilnius_Seimas.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_Seimas.jpg) [Seimas Palace](/wiki/Seimas_Palace "Seimas Palace") in Vilnius, where the [parliamentarians of Lithuania](/wiki/Seimas "Seimas") convenes [![A large room with horseshoe-shaped seating, seen from above](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Baltijas_Asamblejas_31.sesija_Vi%C4%BC%C5%86%C4%81_%288169464170%29.jpg/220px-Baltijas_Asamblejas_31.sesija_Vi%C4%BC%C5%86%C4%81_%288169464170%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Baltijas_Asamblejas_31.sesija_Vi%C4%BC%C5%86%C4%81_(8169464170).jpg) A Seimas [plenary session](/wiki/Plenary_session "Plenary session")

Vilnius is the seat of Lithuania's [national government](/wiki/Government_of_Lithuania "Government of Lithuania"). The country's two chief officers have their offices in Vilnius. The [president](/wiki/President_of_Lithuania "President of Lithuania") resides at the [Presidential Palace](/wiki/Presidential_Palace,_Vilnius "Presidential Palace, Vilnius") in [Daukanto Square](/wiki/Daukanto_Square "Daukanto Square"),^[\[170\]](#cite_note-170)^ and the [prime minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Lithuania "Prime Minister of Lithuania")'s seat is at the Government of Lithuania office in Gediminas Avenue.^[\[171\]](#cite_note-171)^ According to law, the president has a residence in Vilnius' Turniškės district near the Neris.^[\[172\]](#cite_note-172)^^[\[173\]](#cite_note-173)^ The prime minister is also has entitled to a residence in Turniškės district during their term in office.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-174)^ Government ministries are located throughout the city, many in the Old Town.^[\[175\]](#cite_note-175)^{#cite_ref-175}

The [Seimas](/wiki/Seimas "Seimas") of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania primarily gathered in Vilnius.^[\[176\]](#cite_note-176)^ The present-day Seimas meets at the [Seimas Palace](/wiki/Seimas_Palace "Seimas Palace") in Gediminas Avenue.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-177)^{#cite_ref-177}

Lithuania's highest courts are in Vilnius. The [Supreme Court of Lithuania](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Lithuania "Supreme Court of Lithuania") (Lithuanian: *Lietuvos Aukščiausiasis Teismas* ), which reviews criminal and civil cases, is in Gynėjų Street.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-178)^ The [Supreme Administrative Court of Lithuania](/wiki/Supreme_Administrative_Court_of_Lithuania "Supreme Administrative Court of Lithuania") (Lithuanian: *Lietuvos vyriausiasis administracinis teismas* ), which adjudicates litigation against public bodies, is in Žygimantų Street.^[\[179\]](#cite_note-179)^ The [Constitutional Court of Lithuania](/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Lithuania "Constitutional Court of Lithuania") (Lithuanian: *Lietuvos Respublikos Konstitucinis Teismas* ), an advisory body with authority over the constitutionality of laws, meets in the Constitutional Court Palace in Gediminas Avenue.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-180)^ The [Lithuanian Tribunal](/wiki/Lithuanian_Tribunal "Lithuanian Tribunal"), the highest [appellate court](/wiki/Appellate_court "Appellate court") for the nobility of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania and established by [Stephen Báthory](/wiki/Stephen_B%C3%A1thory "Stephen Báthory") in 1581, was in Vilnius until the [Third Partition of Poland](/wiki/Third_Partition_of_Poland "Third Partition of Poland") in 1795.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-181)^{#cite_ref-181}  

### Special services {#Special_services}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Special services")\]  
[![A police officer on a motorized scooter](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Segway_cop.jpg/92px-Segway_cop.jpg)](/wiki/File:Segway_cop.jpg)  
A police officer patrolling with a [Segway](/wiki/Segway "Segway")  
[![Exterior of a large, gray, modern building](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Emergency_Response_Center_%28Vilnius%29.jpg/192px-Emergency_Response_Center_%28Vilnius%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Emergency_Response_Center_(Vilnius).jpg)  
The Emergency Response Center in [Antakalnis](/wiki/Antakalnis "Antakalnis"), which handles emergency calls in Vilnius

Security in Vilnius is primarily the responsibility of the *Vilniaus apskrities vyriausiasis policijos komisariatas* , the highest police office in the city, and local police offices. Its main responsibilities are ensuring public order and safety, reporting and investigating criminal offenses, and traffic control.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-182)^ In 2016, the city had 1,500 police officers.^[\[183\]](#cite_note-183)^ The [Public Security Service](/wiki/Public_Security_Service_(Lithuania) "Public Security Service (Lithuania)") is responsible for the prompt restoration of public order in special situations and ensuring the protection of important state objects and escorted subjects.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-184)^{#cite_ref-184}

*Vilniaus apskrities priešgaisrinė gelbėjimo valdyba* is the primary governing body of Vilnius's [firefighters](/wiki/Firefighter "Firefighter").^[\[185\]](#cite_note-185)^ There were 1,287 fire incidents in the first nine months of 2018, killing six people and injuring 16.^[\[186\]](#cite_note-186)^{#cite_ref-186}

*Vilniaus greitosios medicinos pagalbos stotis* is responsible for [emergency medical services](/wiki/Emergency_medical_services "Emergency medical services") in the city, and the EMS telephone number is 033.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-187)^ Established in 1902, it is one of eastern Europe's oldest EMS institutions.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-vgmps-188)^ Many doctors and other personnel received medals for their assistance to victims of the 1991 January Events.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-vgmps-188)^ The common number for contacting emergency services in Vilnius and other parts of Lithuania is 112.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-189)^{#cite_ref-189}  

Cityscape {#Cityscape}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Cityscape")\]  
See also: [Vilnius Central Business District](/wiki/Vilnius_Central_Business_District "Vilnius Central Business District")  
[![Large photo of Vilnius, seen from above](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Vilnius_Old_Town_Skyline_at_dusk%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/1000px-Vilnius_Old_Town_Skyline_at_dusk%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_Old_Town_Skyline_at_dusk,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg)  
[](/wiki/File:Vilnius_Old_Town_Skyline_at_dusk,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg "File:Vilnius Old Town Skyline at dusk, Lithuania - Diliff.jpg")
Panorama of Vilnius Old Town, seen from [Gediminas' Tower](/wiki/Gediminas%27_Tower "Gediminas' Tower") at dusk. Vilnius has one of the largest and best-preserved old towns in [northern](/wiki/Northern_Europe "Northern Europe"), [eastern](/wiki/Eastern_Europe "Eastern Europe"), and [central Europe](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe").^[\[18\]](#cite_note-unesco-18)^^[\[14\]](#cite_note-TheCapital-14)^^[\[15\]](#cite_note-VWH-15)^^[\[16\]](#cite_note-Lurk-16)^ Its skyline is dominated by [spires of churches](/wiki/List_of_churches_in_Vilnius "List of churches in Vilnius") dating to the Grand Duchy of Lithuania.^[\[190\]](#cite_note-190)^^[\[15\]](#cite_note-VWH-15)^  

### Urbanism and architecture {#Urbanism_and_architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Urbanism and architecture")\]
[![Exterior of two old, red churches](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Vilnius_St_Anns_church.jpg/220px-Vilnius_St_Anns_church.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_St_Anns_church.jpg) [St. Anne's Church](/wiki/Church_of_St._Anne,_Vilnius "Church of St. Anne, Vilnius") and the [Church of St. Francis and St. Bernard](/wiki/Church_of_St._Francis_and_St._Bernard,_Vilnius "Church of St. Francis and St. Bernard, Vilnius") are examples of [Gothic architecture in Lithuania](/wiki/Gothic_architecture_in_Lithuania "Gothic architecture in Lithuania"). [![Interior of a large Baroque church](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/220px-St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg)](/wiki/File:St._Peter_and_St._Paul%27s_Church_1,_Vilnius,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg) The [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture") [Church of St. Peter and St. Paul](/wiki/Church_of_St._Peter_and_St._Paul,_Vilnius "Church of St. Peter and St. Paul, Vilnius") was built by [Michał Kazimierz Pac](/wiki/Micha%C5%82_Kazimierz_Pac "Michał Kazimierz Pac") to commemorate victory over the Muscovites and their expulsion from Vilnius after six years of occupation.

The Old Town covers about 3.6 km^2^ (1.4 sq mi), and its history dates to the [Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic"). The glacial hills were intermittently occupied, and a wooden castle was built at the confluence of the Neris and Vilnia  1000 AD to fortify [Gedimino Hill](/wiki/Gedimino_Hill "Gedimino Hill"). The settlement developed into a town in the 13th century, when the [pagan](/wiki/Pagan "Pagan") [Baltic people](/wiki/Baltic_people "Baltic people") were invaded by [Western Europeans](/wiki/Western_Europeans "Western Europeans") during the [Lithuanian Crusade](/wiki/Lithuanian_Crusade "Lithuanian Crusade"). Around 1323 (the first written sources about Vilnia), it was the capital of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania and had a few brick buildings. By the 15th century, the duchy extended from the [Baltic](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea") to the [Black Sea](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea") (primarily present-day Belarus, Ukraine and Russia). The historic centre consists of [three castles](/wiki/Vilnius_Castle_Complex "Vilnius Castle Complex") (Upper, Lower and Curved) and the area previously encircled by the [Wall of Vilnius](/wiki/Wall_of_Vilnius "Wall of Vilnius"). It is mainly circular, centered on the original castle site. Streets are small and narrow, with large squares later developed.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-unesco-18)^ [Pilies Street](/wiki/Pilies_Street "Pilies Street"), the main artery, links the Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania with Vilnius Town Hall. Other streets are lined with the palaces of feudal lords and landlords, churches, shops and craftspeople's workrooms.{#cite_ref-unesco_18-2}

Historic buildings feature [Gothic](/wiki/Gothic_architecture "Gothic architecture"),^[\[191\]](#cite_note-191)^ [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance_architecture "Renaissance architecture"),^[\[192\]](#cite_note-192)^ [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque_architecture "Baroque architecture")^[\[193\]](#cite_note-193)^ and [classical architecture](/wiki/Classical_architecture "Classical architecture").^[\[194\]](#cite_note-194)^ The variety of preserved churches and former palaces of the Lithuanian nobility exemplifies Vilnius' multicultural heritage.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-unesco-18)^^[\[195\]](#cite_note-195)^{#cite_ref-195}

Lithuanians and others shaped the development of the capital, with Western and Eastern influences. Lithuania was [Christianized](/wiki/Christianization_of_Lithuania "Christianization of Lithuania") in 1387, but Eastern Orthodoxy and the growing importance of [Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism") led to construction of the [Orthodox Cathedral of the Theotokos](/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Theotokos,_Vilnius "Cathedral of the Theotokos, Vilnius") and the [Great Synagogue of Vilna](/wiki/Great_Synagogue_of_Vilna "Great Synagogue of Vilna")).^[\[18\]](#cite_note-unesco-18)^{#cite_ref-unesco_18-4}
[![An ornate chapel, seen from the side](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Vilnius_Cathedral_Chapel_of_Saint_Casimir%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/220px-Vilnius_Cathedral_Chapel_of_Saint_Casimir%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_Cathedral_Chapel_of_Saint_Casimir,_Vilnius,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg) The 17th-century Chapel of Saint Casimir, the [patron saint](/wiki/Patron_saint "Patron saint") of Lithuania and its youth, in [Vilnius Cathedral](/wiki/Vilnius_Cathedral "Vilnius Cathedral")

Disasters resulted in building reconstructions in [Vilnian Baroque](/wiki/Vilnian_Baroque "Vilnian Baroque") style, which later influenced the Grand Duchy of Lithuania.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-unesco-18)^^[\[17\]](#cite_note-VilniusBaroqueVWH-17)^ Artists such as [Matteo Castelli](/wiki/Matteo_Castelli "Matteo Castelli") and [Pietro Perti](/wiki/Pietro_Perti "Pietro Perti")) from the present-day [Canton of Ticino](/wiki/Canton_of_Ticino "Canton of Ticino") were preferred by the Grand Duke and local nobility, and designed the [Chapel of Saint Casimir](/wiki/Chapel_of_Saint_Casimir "Chapel of Saint Casimir").^[\[196\]](#cite_note-196)^ The Lithuanian [Laurynas Gucevičius](/wiki/Laurynas_Gucevi%C4%8Dius "Laurynas Gucevičius") was a noted classical architect in the city.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-197)^{#cite_ref-197}

The 352-hectare (870-acre) Old Town was designated as a [UNESCO World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") in 1994. The Vilnius Historic Centre is noted for maintaining its medieval street pattern with no significant gaps. Some places were damaged during Lithuania's occupations and wars, including [Cathedral Square](/wiki/Cathedral_Square,_Vilnius "Cathedral Square, Vilnius") (demolished in 1795) and a square east of the [Church of All Saints](/wiki/Church_of_All_Saints,_Vilnius "Church of All Saints, Vilnius") where the [Convent of the Barefoot Carmelites](/wiki/Church_of_St._Joseph_the_Betrothed,_Vilnius "Church of St. Joseph the Betrothed, Vilnius") stood with [Vice-Chancellor](/wiki/Deputy_Chancellor_of_Lithuania "Deputy Chancellor of Lithuania") [Stefan Pac](/wiki/Stefan_Pac "Stefan Pac")'s Baroque [Church of St. Joseph the Betrothed](/wiki/Church_of_St._Joseph_the_Betrothed,_Vilnius "Church of St. Joseph the Betrothed, Vilnius") (both demolished by the [tsar](/wiki/Tsar "Tsar"). The Great Synagogue and part of the buildings in [Vokiečių Street](/wiki/Vokie%C4%8Di%C5%B3_Street "Vokiečių Street") were demolished after World War II.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-unesco-18)^{#cite_ref-unesco_18-6}

Vilnius covers 401 square kilometres (155 sq mi), of which one-fifth is developed; the remainder is greenspace and water. The city is known as one of Europe's "greenest" capital cities.^[\[198\]](#cite_note-198)^{#cite_ref-198}  

### Crypts {#Crypts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Crypts")\]

Notable Lithuanian Catholics are interred in the crypts of Vilnius Cathedral. Grand Duke [Alexander Jagiellon](/wiki/Alexander_Jagiellon "Alexander Jagiellon"), Queen [Elizabeth of Austria](/wiki/Elizabeth_of_Austria_(1436%E2%80%931505) "Elizabeth of Austria (1436–1505)"), [Barbara Radziwiłł](/wiki/Barbara_Radziwi%C5%82%C5%82 "Barbara Radziwiłł"), and the heart of Grand Duke Władysław IV Vasa are buried at the Royal Mausoleum. These crypts have one of the country's oldest frescoes, painted in the late 14th or early 15th century after Lithuania was Christianized.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-199)^{#cite_ref-199}  

### Housing {#Housing}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Housing")\]
[![Pedestrians on a narrow street](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Vilnius_Pilies_street.jpg/220px-Vilnius_Pilies_street.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_Pilies_street.jpg) Pilies Street has a medieval atmosphere.

Vilnius Old Town (Lithuanian: *Vilniaus senamiestis* ), with medieval stone-paved streets, and Užupis have prestigious housing, with [apartments](/wiki/Apartment "Apartment") featuring views of iconic churches and urban landmarks (particularly [Gediminas Tower](/wiki/Gediminas_Tower "Gediminas Tower")), enclosed inner courtyards, high ceilings, attics, non-standard layouts and luxurious interiors;^[\[200\]](#cite_note-asa-200)^ Flats in these neighbourhoods may cost millions of [euros](/wiki/Euro "Euro").^[\[201\]](#cite_note-201)^ Traffic jams, expensive parking, air pollution, high maintenance costs and limitations on renovation, however, also encourage wealthy Vilnians to buy or build [private houses](/wiki/Private_house "Private house") in outlying parts of the city such as [Balsiai](/w/index.php?title=Balsiai&action=edit&redlink=1 "Balsiai (page does not exist)"), [Bajorai](/wiki/Bajorai "Bajorai"), [Pavilnys](/w/index.php?title=Pavilnys&action=edit&redlink=1 "Pavilnys (page does not exist)"), [Kalnėnai](/w/index.php?title=Kaln%C4%97nai&action=edit&redlink=1 "Kalnėnai (page does not exist)") and [Pilaitė](/wiki/Pilait%C4%97 "Pilaitė") or the nearby [Vilnius District Municipality](/wiki/Vilnius_District_Municipality "Vilnius District Municipality").^[\[200\]](#cite_note-asa-200)^ Around 21,000 residents live in the Old Town, and 7,000 in Užupis.^[\[202\]](#cite_note-Mikrorajonai-202)^{#cite_ref-Mikrorajonai_202-0}
[![A scenic riverside neighborhood, seen from above](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Valakampiai_neighborhood.jpg/220px-Valakampiai_neighborhood.jpg)](/wiki/File:Valakampiai_neighborhood.jpg) Part of the Valakampiai neighborhood in [Antakalnis](/wiki/Antakalnis "Antakalnis") on the Neris, seen from [Verkiai Palace](/wiki/Verkiai_Palace "Verkiai Palace") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/82/Savanoriu_avenue_Vilnius.JPG/220px-Savanoriu_avenue_Vilnius.JPG)](/wiki/File:Savanoriu_avenue_Vilnius.JPG) Helios City complex in [Naujamiestis](/wiki/Naujamiestis,_Vilnius "Naujamiestis, Vilnius") with [shopping mall](/wiki/Shopping_mall "Shopping mall") and apartments

[Valakampiai](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valakampiai "lt:Valakampiai") and [Turniškės](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turni%C5%A1k%C4%97s "lt:Turniškės") are prestigious neighborhoods, with private houses on large lots surrounded by [pine](/wiki/Scots_pine "Scots pine") forests which are easily accessible from the city centre. Wealthy people and heads of state (such as the president) live there, and most of the larger private houses costs millions of euros.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-asa-200)^^[\[203\]](#cite_note-203)^ Part of the [Žvėrynas](/wiki/%C5%BDv%C4%97rynas "Žvėrynas") neighbourhood has luxurious private houses near Vingis Park, but it also has Soviet-era apartment buildings and wooden houses in poor condition.^[\[202\]](#cite_note-Mikrorajonai-202)^^[\[200\]](#cite_note-asa-200)^{#cite_ref-asa_200-3}

Neighbourhoods around the Old Town (Antakalnis, Žirmūnai, Naujamiestis, and Žvėrynas) have a variety of flats and green space, and are popular with [middle-class](/wiki/Middle_class "Middle class") residents. Wealthier people live in a new construction or renovated Soviet-era apartments.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-asa-200)^ The government is supportive of renovation, and reimburses 30 percent or more of the cost.^[\[204\]](#cite_note-204)^ Poorer residents and low-income [pensioners](/wiki/Pensioner "Pensioner"), however, foster [regionalism](/wiki/Regionalism_(politics) "Regionalism (politics)").^[\[205\]](#cite_note-205)^^[\[206\]](#cite_note-206)^{#cite_ref-206}

More-distant neighbourhoods, such as Lazdynai, Karoliniškės, Viršuliškės, [Šeškinė](/wiki/%C5%A0e%C5%A1kin%C4%97 "Šeškinė"), Justiniškės, Pašilaičiai, Fabijoniškės and [Naujininkai](/wiki/Naujininkai "Naujininkai"), have more-affordable housing. Their disadvantages are a longer commute, unrenovated Soviet-era [high-rise buildings](/wiki/High-rise_building "High-rise building"), traffic congestion and a shortage of parking spaces near older apartments.^[\[200\]](#cite_note-asa-200)^^[\[207\]](#cite_note-207)^{#cite_ref-207}
[![19th-century painting of a large church on a river](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Vilnia%2C_%C5%9Anipi%C5%A1ki%2C_Jezuicki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8F%2C_%D0%A1%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%96%D0%BF%D1%96%D1%88%D0%BA%D1%96%2C_%D0%95%D0%B7%D1%83%D1%96%D1%86%D0%BA%D1%96_%28L._Bichebois%2C_1848-49%29.jpg/220px-Vilnia%2C_%C5%9Anipi%C5%A1ki%2C_Jezuicki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8F%2C_%D0%A1%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%96%D0%BF%D1%96%D1%88%D0%BA%D1%96%2C_%D0%95%D0%B7%D1%83%D1%96%D1%86%D0%BA%D1%96_%28L._Bichebois%2C_1848-49%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnia,_%C5%9Anipi%C5%A1ki,_Jezuicki._%D0%92%D1%96%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8F,_%D0%A1%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%96%D0%BF%D1%96%D1%88%D0%BA%D1%96,_%D0%95%D0%B7%D1%83%D1%96%D1%86%D0%BA%D1%96_(L._Bichebois,_1848-49).jpg) Mid-19th-century painting of the Chapel of Jesus of Šnipiškės

The [Šnipiškės](/wiki/%C5%A0nipi%C5%A1k%C4%97s "Šnipiškės") eldership has received significant investment during the 2010s. The area was first mentioned in 1536, when Grand Duke Sigismund I the Old ordered [Ulrich Hosius](/wiki/Ulrich_Hosius "Ulrich Hosius") to build a wooden bridge over the Neris and a suburb developed around the bridge. That century, a building for [Muscovite](/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow "Grand Duchy of Moscow") and [Tatar](/wiki/Tatars "Tatars") messengers was built by the magistrate of Vilnius north of Šnipiškės.^[\[208\]](#cite_note-208)^ The Jesuit [Church of St. Raphael the Archangel](/wiki/Church_of_St._Raphael_the_Archangel,_Vilnius "Church of St. Raphael the Archangel, Vilnius") and monastery and housing for wealthy and middle-class townspeople were built in Šnipiškės during the 18th century. Craftspeople lived on the outskirts, where a smoking-pipe factory, sawmills and a small candy factory were built. The 8-hectare (20-acre) Skansenas neighbourhood, west of the Kalvarijų market,^[\[209\]](#cite_note-209)^ has late-19th-century wooden houses. Nearby Piromontas^[\[210\]](#cite_note-210)^ was built at the same time.{#cite_ref-210}

During the 1960s, Šnipiškės was renamed the [New City Centre](/wiki/Vilnius_Central_Business_District "Vilnius Central Business District"). It had the city's first pedestrian zone and a number of buildings, including the country's largest shopping centre, a large hotel, a planetarium, a museum and a number of ministries of the Lithuanian SSR, were built before 1990.^[\[211\]](#cite_note-211)^^[\[212\]](#cite_note-212)^^[\[213\]](#cite_note-213)^^[\[214\]](#cite_note-214)^^[\[215\]](#cite_note-215)^ Šnipiškės north of [Konstitucijos Avenue](/wiki/Konstitucijos_Avenue "Konstitucijos Avenue") was underdeveloped until the early 2000s, when the new [Vilnius city municipality building](/wiki/Vilnius_city_municipality_building "Vilnius city municipality building") spurred construction of Europa Square with a shopping centre, a 33-story office building and a 27-story apartment building. The former Museum of the Revolution became the National Art Gallery in the late 2000s.^[\[216\]](#cite_note-216)^{#cite_ref-216}
[![Aerial view of dense riverside housing](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/3/3b/Paupys_district_in_Vilnius_by_Augustas_Did%C5%BEgalvis.jpg/220px-Paupys_district_in_Vilnius_by_Augustas_Did%C5%BEgalvis.jpg)](/wiki/File:Paupys_district_in_Vilnius_by_Augustas_Did%C5%BEgalvis.jpg) Modern housing in Paupys

According to economists, the number of transactions and the housing affordability index reached record highs in 2019 because of increased city-residents' income and slowing price increases for flats.^[\[217\]](#cite_note-217)^ One-fourth of residents 26 to 35 years old still live in homes owned by their parents or other relatives, however, the highest percentage in the Baltic states.^[\[218\]](#cite_note-218)^{#cite_ref-218}  

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Demographics")\]  
Main article: [Demographics of Vilnius](/wiki/Demographics_of_Vilnius "Demographics of Vilnius")  
Further information: [Demographic history of Vilnius](/wiki/Demographic_history_of_Vilnius "Demographic history of Vilnius") and [Demographic history of the Vilnius region](/wiki/Demographic_history_of_the_Vilnius_region "Demographic history of the Vilnius region")
[![A red-and-blue graph](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Vilnius_population_pyramid.svg/220px-Vilnius_population_pyramid.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_population_pyramid.svg) Vilnius [population pyramid](/wiki/Population_pyramid "Population pyramid") in 2021

In the eldership of [Vilkpėdė](/wiki/Vilkp%C4%97d%C4%97 "Vilkpėdė"), remnants of a [Magdalenian](/wiki/Magdalenian "Magdalenian") settlement were found which date to  10000 BC. Kairėnai, Pūčkoriai and Naujoji Vilnia had large settlements during the first millennium AD.^[\[219\]](#cite_note-historyvle-219)^ The most densely-populated area was the confluence of the Neris and Vilnia, which had fortified homesteads.^[\[219\]](#cite_note-historyvle-219)^{#cite_ref-historyvle_219-1}

According to some historians, Vilnius could have been a city during the [Kingdom of Lithuania](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Lithuania "Kingdom of Lithuania") times: King [Mindaugas](/wiki/Mindaugas "Mindaugas") did not permanently live there, however, may have built Lithuania's first Catholic church for his [coronation](/wiki/Coronation "Coronation") there. It is well established, however, that Vilnius existed as a city during the times of [Traidenis](/wiki/Traidenis "Traidenis") and [Vytenis](/wiki/Vytenis "Vytenis"). The first mention in the historical sources as a capital in 1323 in the [letters to the Western cities](/wiki/Letters_of_Gediminas "Letters of Gediminas") of [Gediminas](/wiki/Gediminas "Gediminas").

It became a multicultural city, with 14th-century sources noting that it consisted of a Great (Lithuanian) city and a [Ruthenian](/wiki/Ruthenians "Ruthenians") one. By the 16th century, [German](/wiki/Germans "Germans") merchants, artisans, Jews and [Tatars](/wiki/Tatars "Tatars") had also settled in Vilnius. During the 16th-- and 17th-century [Reformation](/wiki/Reformation "Reformation") and [Counter-Reformation](/wiki/Counter-Reformation "Counter-Reformation"), the city's Polish-speaking population began to grow; by the middle of the 17th century, most writing was in Polish.^[\[219\]](#cite_note-historyvle-219)^ City was inhabited by a large number of [Italian](/wiki/Italians "Italians") and [Swiss](/wiki/Swiss_people "Swiss people") artisans as well and generally all the European nations were presented to an extent (those included [Vilnius university](/wiki/Vilnius_university "Vilnius university") professors and students among whom there were [French](/wiki/French_people "French people"), [Spanish](/wiki/Spaniards "Spaniards"), [Swedes](/wiki/Swedes "Swedes") and even some [Croatians](/wiki/Croatians "Croatians") as Tomaš Zdelarius, musicians at the [Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania](/wiki/Palace_of_the_Grand_Dukes_of_Lithuania "Palace of the Grand Dukes of Lithuania") or such military servants as [Hungarian](/wiki/Hungarians "Hungarians") [Gáspár Bekes](/wiki/G%C3%A1sp%C3%A1r_Bekes "Gáspár Bekes")). Because of many nations inhabiting the city, in the 16th-18th. centuries it was known and nicknamed in Western sources as [Babylon](/wiki/Babylon "Babylon") of Europe.^[\[4\]](#cite_note-S._Bodniak_1930_p._37-4)^{#cite_ref-S._Bodniak_1930_p._37_4-1}

By the inter-war period, after the brief [Polish--Lithuanian War](/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_War "Polish–Lithuanian War") and the annexation of the so-called [Republic of Central Lithuania](/wiki/Republic_of_Central_Lithuania "Republic of Central Lithuania") by Poland, the population became overwhelmingly Polish with very significant Jewish minority. Because of the annexation, the 1931 Polish census recorded only 0.8% Lithuanians. After World War II, the number of ethnic Lithuanians in Vilnius rebounded; however, Lithuanization was soon replaced with [Sovietization](/wiki/Sovietization_of_the_Baltic_states "Sovietization of the Baltic states"),^[\[220\]](#cite_note-diana427-220)^^[\[221\]](#cite_note-Snyder_92-93-221)^ and the population became a mix of Lithuanians, Russians and Poles. Following independence in 1990, for the first time in modern history Lithuanians became a clear majority, increasing to 63.2 percent in 2011 and 67.4 percent in 2021.^[\[222\]](#cite_note-2011census-222)^^[\[223\]](#cite_note-223)^^[\[224\]](#cite_note-224)^{#cite_ref-224}

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Economy")\]  
[![Aerial view of the skyline and a bridge](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Vilnius_Modern_Skyline_At_Dusk%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/650px-Vilnius_Modern_Skyline_At_Dusk%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_Modern_Skyline_At_Dusk,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg)  
[](/wiki/File:Vilnius_Modern_Skyline_At_Dusk,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg "File:Vilnius Modern Skyline At Dusk, Lithuania - Diliff.jpg")
The skyline at dusk, with the [Vilnius Central Business District](/wiki/Vilnius_Central_Business_District "Vilnius Central Business District") housing [banks](/wiki/List_of_banks_in_Lithuania "List of banks in Lithuania"), financial services and businesses headquarters
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/7a/Europa_Tower_in_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania.jpg/180px-Europa_Tower_in_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania.jpg)](/wiki/File:Europa_Tower_in_Vilnius,_Lithuania.jpg) [Europa Tower](/wiki/Europa_Tower "Europa Tower"), the [tallest building in the Baltics](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_the_Baltic_states "List of tallest buildings in the Baltic states"), is a symbol of modern Vilnius.

Vilnius is Lithuania's economic centre, with a per-capita GDP in the metropolitan area of almost [€](/wiki/EUR "EUR")30,000.^[\[233\]](#cite_note-233)^ The city's budget reached €1.0 billion in 2022.^[\[234\]](#cite_note-234)^ In the second quarter of 2024, the average monthly salary in Vilnius was €2,501.1 (gross) and €1,526.2 (net).^[\[235\]](#cite_note-235)^{#cite_ref-235}
[![Aerial view of a modern, oval building](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/79/K29_business_centre_in_Vilnius_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg/180px-K29_business_centre_in_Vilnius_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg)](/wiki/File:K29_business_centre_in_Vilnius_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg) The K29 business centre is the first office in the Baltic states to receive an excellent [BREEAM](/wiki/BREEAM "BREEAM") rating.^[\[236\]](#cite_note-236)^

Lithuania's economic growth has been uneven, with [GDP](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") per capita at nearly 110 percent of the EU average in Vilnius but from 42 to 77 percent in other regions. The country's [convergence](/wiki/Convergence_(economics) "Convergence (economics)") is fuelled by two regions (Vilnius and [Kaunas County](/wiki/Kaunas_County "Kaunas County")) which produce 42 and 20 percent of the national GDP, respectively. From 2014 to 2016, the Vilnius region grew by 4.6 percent.^[\[237\]](#cite_note-237)^{#cite_ref-237}

The supply of new housing in Vilnius and its suburbs has reached post-recession highs, and the stock of unsold apartments in Lithuania's three largest cities has begun to increase since the beginning of 2017. Demand for housing is strong, fuelled by rising wages, benign financial conditions and positive expectations. In the first half of 2018, the number of monthly transactions was the highest since its 2007--2008 peak.^[\[238\]](#cite_note-238)^ Most [foreign direct investment](/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment "Foreign direct investment") and productive public investment in Lithuania is concentrated on Vilnius and Kaunas.^[\[239\]](#cite_note-239)^ Vilnius Industrial Park, 18.5 kilometres from the city, is intended for commercial and industrial use.^[\[240\]](#cite_note-240)^{#cite_ref-240}  

### Science and research {#Science_and_research}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Science and research")\]
[![An old university courtyard](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Vilnius_University_M._K._Sarbievijus_Courtyard%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/220px-Vilnius_University_M._K._Sarbievijus_Courtyard%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_University_M._K._Sarbievijus_Courtyard,_Vilnius,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg) The Vilnius University Astronomical Observatory

Vilnius resident [Tito Livio Burattini](/wiki/Tito_Livio_Burattini "Tito Livio Burattini") published *Misura universale* in 1675, in which he first suggested the term [metre](/wiki/Metre "Metre") as a unit of length.^[\[241\]](#cite_note-241)^ The [Vilnius University Astronomical Observatory](/wiki/Vilnius_University_Astronomical_Observatory "Vilnius University Astronomical Observatory"), established in 1753 at the initiative of [Thomas Zebrowski](/wiki/Thomas_Zebrowski "Thomas Zebrowski"), was one of Europe's first [observatories](/wiki/Observatory "Observatory") and the first in the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.^[\[242\]](#cite_note-242)^ [Marcin Odlanicki Poczobutt](/wiki/Marcin_Odlanicki_Poczobutt "Marcin Odlanicki Poczobutt") led the reconstruction of the observatory, designed by [Marcin Knackfus](/wiki/Marcin_Knackfus "Marcin Knackfus"), from 1770 to 1772. Poczobutt began his [astronomical observations](/wiki/Observational_astronomy "Observational astronomy") in 1773, recording them in the journal ([French](/wiki/French_language "French language"): *Cahiers des observations* ), and created the constellation *[Taurus Poniatovii](/wiki/Taurus_Poniatovii "Taurus Poniatovii")* .^[\[243\]](#cite_note-243)^ [Jean-Emmanuel Gilibert](/wiki/Jean-Emmanuel_Gilibert "Jean-Emmanuel Gilibert") established the [Botanical Garden of Vilnius University](/wiki/Botanical_Garden_of_Vilnius_University "Botanical Garden of Vilnius University") in 1781 with over 2,000 plants, and provided the first [herbariums](/wiki/Herbarium "Herbarium"), collections of stuffed animals and birds, [fossil plants](/wiki/Paleobotany "Paleobotany"), animal remains, and a collection of [minerals](/wiki/Minerals "Minerals") to Vilnius University.,^[\[244\]](#cite_note-244)^ The observatory published the Russian Empire's first [exact sciences](/wiki/Exact_sciences "Exact sciences") journal, the *Journal of Mathematical Sciences* (Russian: Вестник математических наук), after the Third Partition of Poland.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-Klimka-120)^{#cite_ref-Klimka_120-1}
[![Aerial view of modern buildings and green space](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1b/Scientific_centers_in_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_in_2017.jpg/220px-Scientific_centers_in_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_in_2017.jpg)](/wiki/File:Scientific_centers_in_Vilnius,_Lithuania_in_2017.jpg) Scientific centres and university faculties at Sunrise Valley

Sunrise Valley Science and Technology Park (Lithuanian: *Saulėtekio slėnio mokslo ir technologijų parkas* ) is a non-profit organization which was founded in 2003. Over 20,000 students study in the Vilnius University and [Vilnius Gediminas Technical University](/wiki/Vilnius_Gediminas_Technical_University "Vilnius Gediminas Technical University") facilities in Sunrise Valley, and 5,000 scientists conduct research in its science centres.^[\[245\]](#cite_note-245)^{#cite_ref-245}

The Centre for Physical Sciences and Technology (Lithuanian: *Fizinių ir technologijos mokslų centras* , FTMC) is the country's largest scientific research institution, specialising in [laser](/wiki/Laser "Laser") technology, [optoelectronics](/wiki/Optoelectronics "Optoelectronics"), [nuclear physics](/wiki/Nuclear_physics "Nuclear physics"), [organic chemistry](/wiki/Organic_chemistry "Organic chemistry"), [bio](/wiki/Biotechnology "Biotechnology") and [nanotechnology](/wiki/Nanotechnology "Nanotechnology"), electrochemical [materials science](/wiki/Materials_science "Materials science"), and [electronics](/wiki/Electronics "Electronics"). The centre was created in 2010 with the merger of the institutes of chemistry, physics and semiconductor physics in Vilnius and the Textile institute in Kaunas.^[\[246\]](#cite_note-246)^ With 250 laboratories (24 open to the public), it can accommodate over 700 researchers and students.^[\[247\]](#cite_note-247)^ The centre has a [PhD program](/wiki/Doctor_of_Philosophy "Doctor of Philosophy") and hosts annual conferences of PhD students and young researchers.^[\[248\]](#cite_note-248)^ FTMC is the founder and sole shareholder of the Science and Technology Park of Institute of Physics in Savanorių Avenue, which assists companies with [research and development](/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and development").^[\[249\]](#cite_note-249)^{#cite_ref-249}

Vilnius University's Laser Research Centre (Lithuanian: *Vilniaus universiteto Lazerinių tyrimų centras* ) is one of five departments in the university's Faculty of Physics, which prepares physicists, laser physicists and laser-technology specialists. The department conducts research in [laser physics](/wiki/Laser_physics "Laser physics"), [nonlinear optics](/wiki/Nonlinear_optics "Nonlinear optics"), optical-component characterization, [biophotonics](/wiki/Biophotonics "Biophotonics") and laser [microtechnology](/wiki/Microtechnology "Microtechnology").^[\[250\]](#cite_note-250)^ Lithuania has over 50 percent of the world's market share in [ultrashort pulses](/wiki/Ultrashort_pulse "Ultrashort pulse") lasers produced by Vilnius-based companies.^[\[251\]](#cite_note-laser-251)^ A laser system was produced in 2019 for the [Extreme Light Infrastructure](/wiki/Extreme_Light_Infrastructure "Extreme Light Infrastructure") laboratory in [Szeged](/wiki/Szeged "Szeged") which produces high-intensity, ultra-short pulses with a peak power up to 1,000 times that of the most powerful [nuclear power plant](/wiki/Nuclear_power_plant "Nuclear power plant") in the United States.^[\[251\]](#cite_note-laser-251)^ [Corning Inc.](/wiki/Corning_Inc. "Corning Inc.") bought a glass-cutting licence from the Vilnius-based laser company Altechna and for manufacturing [Gorilla Glass](/wiki/Gorilla_Glass "Gorilla Glass").^[\[252\]](#cite_note-252)^{#cite_ref-252}
[![A smiling, bespectacled man speaking into a microphone](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/VSiksnys.jpg/200px-VSiksnys.jpg)](/wiki/File:VSiksnys.jpg) Virginijus Šikšnys is a biochemist at Vilnius University.

The Vilnius University Life Sciences Centre (Lithuanian: *Vilniaus universiteto Gyvybės mokslų centras* ) is a scientific research centre which consists of three institutes: the Institute of Biochemistry, Institute of Biosciences, and Institute of Biotechnology. The centre was opened in 2016 and has 800 students, 120 PhD students, 200 teaching staff, and open-access scientific laboratories with advanced equipment.^[\[253\]](#cite_note-253)^ It has a technology [business incubator](/wiki/Business_incubator "Business incubator") for small and medium businesses in the life sciences or related fields.^[\[254\]](#cite_note-254)^ Vilnius Gediminas Technical University has three research centres at Sunrise Valley: the Civil Engineering Research Centre, Technology Centre for Building Information and Digital Modelling, and Competence Centre of Intermodal Transport and Logistics.^[\[255\]](#cite_note-255)^{#cite_ref-255}

The Lithuanian Centre for Social Sciences (Lithuanian: *Lietuvos socialinių mokslų centras* ), which cooperates with the Lithuanian government, produces and disseminates scientific information in the fields of economics, sociology and law to implement public policy.^[\[256\]](#cite_note-256)^ Santara Valley (Lithuanian: *Santaros slėnis* ) is a science and research facility which focuses on [medicine](/wiki/Medicine "Medicine"), [biopharmaceutical](/wiki/Biopharmaceutical "Biopharmaceutical") and [bioinformatics](/wiki/Bioinformatics "Bioinformatics").^[\[257\]](#cite_note-257)^ The [Vilnius University Faculty of Medicine](/wiki/Vilnius_University_Faculty_of_Medicine "Vilnius University Faculty of Medicine") Science Centre was scheduled for completion in Santara Valley in 2021.^[\[258\]](#cite_note-258)^{#cite_ref-258}

Vilnius University rector [Jonas Kubilius](/wiki/Jonas_Kubilius "Jonas Kubilius"), known for [probabilistic number theory](/wiki/Probabilistic_number_theory "Probabilistic number theory"), the [Kubilius model](/wiki/Kubilius_model "Kubilius model"), the Theorem of Kubilius and [Turán--Kubilius inequality](/wiki/Tur%C3%A1n%E2%80%93Kubilius_inequality "Turán–Kubilius inequality"), successfully resisted attempts to Russify Vilnius University.^[\[259\]](#cite_note-259)^ Vilnius' [Marija Gimbutas](/wiki/Marija_Gimbutas "Marija Gimbutas") was the first to formulate the [Kurgan hypothesis](/wiki/Kurgan_hypothesis "Kurgan hypothesis"). In 1963, [Vytautas Straižys](/wiki/Vytautas_Strai%C5%BEys "Vytautas Straižys") and his colleagues created the [Vilnius photometric system](/wiki/Vilnius_photometric_system "Vilnius photometric system") used in [astronomy](/wiki/Astronomy "Astronomy").^[\[260\]](#cite_note-260)^ [Kavli Prize](/wiki/Kavli_Prize "Kavli Prize") laureate [Virginijus Šikšnys](/wiki/Virginijus_%C5%A0ik%C5%A1nys "Virginijus Šikšnys") invented [CRISPR](/wiki/CRISPR "CRISPR")-[Cas9](/wiki/Cas9 "Cas9") [genetic](/wiki/Gene "Gene") editing.^[\[261\]](#cite_note-261)^{#cite_ref-261}  

### Information technology {#Information_technology}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Information technology")\]
[![Aerial view of modern buildings](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/42/Green_Hall_Complex_in_Vilnius_by_Augustas_Did%C5%BEgalvis.jpg/220px-Green_Hall_Complex_in_Vilnius_by_Augustas_Did%C5%BEgalvis.jpg)](/wiki/File:Green_Hall_Complex_in_Vilnius_by_Augustas_Did%C5%BEgalvis.jpg) The Green Hall business complex in [Žvėrynas](/wiki/%C5%BDv%C4%97rynas "Žvėrynas"), which houses IT companies and Europe's first international Blockchain Centre

Vilnius is attractive for foreign companies because of its qualified employees and good infrastructure.^[\[262\]](#cite_note-262)^ Several schools are preparing skilled specialists, including the [Vilnius University Faculty of Mathematics and Informatics](/wiki/Vilnius_University_Faculty_of_Mathematics_and_Informatics "Vilnius University Faculty of Mathematics and Informatics") and [Vilnius Gediminas Technical University Faculty of Fundamental Sciences](/wiki/Vilnius_Gediminas_Technical_University_Faculty_of_Fundamental_Sciences "Vilnius Gediminas Technical University Faculty of Fundamental Sciences").^[\[263\]](#cite_note-263)^^[\[264\]](#cite_note-264)^ [Information technology](/wiki/Information_technology "Information technology") jobs are well-paid.^[\[265\]](#cite_note-265)^ The 2018 output of the Lituanian IT sector was €2.296 billion, much of which was created in Vilnius.^[\[266\]](#cite_note-266)^{#cite_ref-266}

Vilnius Tech Park in Sapieha Park, the largest IT [startup](/wiki/Startup "Startup") hub in the Baltic and [Nordic countries](/wiki/Nordic_countries "Nordic countries"), unites international startups, technology companies, accelerators, and incubators.^[\[267\]](#cite_note-267)^ *[fDi Intelligence](/wiki/FDi_Intelligence "FDi Intelligence")* ranked Vilnius number one city on its 2019 Tech Start-up FDI Attraction Index.^[\[268\]](#cite_note-268)^{#cite_ref-268}

Vilnius had the world's fastest internet speed in 2011^[\[269\]](#cite_note-269)^ and, despite its fall in the rankings, remains one of the world's fastest.^[\[270\]](#cite_note-270)^ [Vilnius Airport](/wiki/Vilnius_Airport "Vilnius Airport") has one of Europe's fastest airport [Wi-Fi](/wiki/Wi-Fi "Wi-Fi") speeds.^[\[271\]](#cite_note-271)^ The [National Cyber Security Centre of Lithuania](/wiki/National_Cyber_Security_Centre_of_Lithuania "National Cyber Security Centre of Lithuania") was established in Vilnius to address internet attacks on Lithuanian government organizations.^[\[272\]](#cite_note-272)^{#cite_ref-272}

[Bebras](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bebras_(konkursas) "lt:Bebras (konkursas)"), an international informatics and IT contest, has been held annually for pupils in grades three through 12 since 2004.^[\[273\]](#cite_note-273)^ Since 2017, [computer programming](/wiki/Computer_programming "Computer programming") is taught in primary schools.^[\[274\]](#cite_note-274)^{#cite_ref-274}

Vilnius is a popular [fintech](/wiki/Fintech "Fintech") hub due to Lithuania's flexible [e-money](/wiki/E-money "E-money") licence regulations.^[\[275\]](#cite_note-275)^ The Bank of Lithuania granted an e-money licence in 2018 to Vilnius-based Google Payment Lithuania.^[\[276\]](#cite_note-276)^ The startup [Revolut](/wiki/Revolut "Revolut") also has an e-money licence and headquarters in Vilnius, and began moving its clients to the Lithuanian company Revolut Payments in 2019.^[\[277\]](#cite_note-277)^ On 23 January 2019, Europe's first international blockchain centre opened in Vilnius.^[\[278\]](#cite_note-278)^{#cite_ref-278}  

### Finance and banking {#Finance_and_banking}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Finance and banking")\]
[![Aerial view of an old, square building with trees in front](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/LB_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg/220px-LB_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg)](/wiki/File:LB_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg) [Bank of Lithuania](/wiki/Bank_of_Lithuania "Bank of Lithuania") headquarters in [Gediminas Avenue](/wiki/Gediminas_Avenue "Gediminas Avenue")

Vilnius is Lithuania's financial centre. The [Ministry of Finance](/wiki/Ministry_of_Finance_(Lithuania) "Ministry of Finance (Lithuania)") in Vilnius is responsible for an effective public financial policy to ensure the country's economic growth.^[\[279\]](#cite_note-279)^ The [Bank of Lithuania](/wiki/Bank_of_Lithuania "Bank of Lithuania") fosters a reliable financial system and ensures sustainable economic growth.^[\[280\]](#cite_note-280)^ The [Nasdaq Vilnius](/wiki/Nasdaq_Vilnius "Nasdaq Vilnius") stock exchange is in The K29 business centre.^[\[281\]](#cite_note-281)^{#cite_ref-281}

The [National Audit Office of Lithuania](/wiki/National_Audit_Office_of_Lithuania "National Audit Office of Lithuania") (Lithuanian: *Lietuvos Respublikos valstybės kontrolė* ) helps the government manage public funds and property,^[\[282\]](#cite_note-282)^ and the [State Tax Inspectorate](/wiki/State_Tax_Inspectorate "State Tax Inspectorate") (Lithuanian: *Valstybinė mokesčių inspekcija* ) is responsible for collecting and refunding [taxes](/wiki/Taxation_in_Lithuania "Taxation in Lithuania").^[\[283\]](#cite_note-283)^{#cite_ref-283}

In 2023, 13 [banks](/wiki/List_of_banks_in_Lithuania "List of banks in Lithuania") held a bank or specialised-bank licence; six banks are foreign-bank branches. Most of the Lithuanian financial system consists of capital banks of Nordic countries.^[\[284\]](#cite_note-284)^ The two largest banks registered in Lithuania ([SEB bankas](/wiki/SEB_bankas "SEB bankas") and Swedbank) are supervised by the [European Central Bank](/wiki/European_Central_Bank "European Central Bank") and the Bank of Lithuania.^[\[285\]](#cite_note-285)^{#cite_ref-285}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Education")\]  

### Primary and secondary education {#Primary_and_secondary_education}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Primary and secondary education")\]
[![Exterior of a large building with steps and columns](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/2/2d/National_M._K._Ciurlionis_School_of_Art_in_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania.jpg/220px-National_M._K._Ciurlionis_School_of_Art_in_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_M._K._Ciurlionis_School_of_Art_in_Vilnius,_Lithuania.jpg) The National M. K. Čiurlionis School of Art offers free education to talented students.

Primary and lower secondary education is mandatory in Lithuania. Children begin pre-primary education at age six, education is compulsory until age 16. Primary and secondary education is free, but there are also private schools in Vilnius. The country's educational system is governed by the [Ministry of Education, Science and Sports](/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_and_Science_(Lithuania) "Ministry of Education and Science (Lithuania)"), headquartered in Vilnius.^[\[286\]](#cite_note-286)^{#cite_ref-286}

[Cathedral School of Vilnius](/wiki/Cathedral_School_of_Vilnius "Cathedral School of Vilnius"), first mentioned in a 1397 source, is the earliest known Lithuanian school.^[\[219\]](#cite_note-historyvle-219)^ [Vilnius Vytautas the Great Gymnasium](/wiki/Vilnius_Vytautas_the_Great_Gymnasium "Vilnius Vytautas the Great Gymnasium"), established in 1915, is the first Lithuanian [gymnasium](/wiki/Gymnasium_(school) "Gymnasium (school)") in eastern Lithuania.^[\[287\]](#cite_note-287)^ In 2018, the city had 120 schools (not including [preschools](/wiki/Preschool "Preschool")) with 61,123 pupils and 4,955 teachers.^[\[288\]](#cite_note-288)^ Four out of five best rated schools in Lithuania are in Vilnius, and the [Vilnius Lyceum](/wiki/Vilnius_Lyceum "Vilnius Lyceum") is number one.^[\[289\]](#cite_note-289)^{#cite_ref-289}

[Ethnic minorities in Lithuania](/wiki/Ethnic_minorities_in_Lithuania "Ethnic minorities in Lithuania") have their own schools. Vilnius has seven elementary schools, eight primary schools, two [progymnasiums](/wiki/Gymnasium_(school)#School_structure "Gymnasium (school)") and 12 gymnasiums for minority children, with lessons in minority languages. In 2017, 4,658 Poles and 9,274 Russians studied in their languages in the city.^[\[290\]](#cite_note-290)^ Vilnius has 11 [vocational schools](/wiki/Vocational_school "Vocational school").^[\[291\]](#cite_note-291)^{#cite_ref-291}

The [National M. K. Čiurlionis School of Art](/wiki/National_M._K._%C4%8Ciurlionis_School_of_Art "National M. K. Čiurlionis School of Art") is the country's only 12-year art school. The [Vilnius Justinas Vienožinskis Art School](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vilniaus_Justino_Vieno%C5%BEinskio_dail%C4%97s_mokykla "lt:Vilniaus Justino Vienožinskio dailės mokykla") is another art school in Vilnius.

Most school graduates in Vilnius later study at universities or colleges. According to the [OECD](/wiki/OECD "OECD"), 57.5 percent of 25-- to 34-year-olds in Lithuania had a tertiary education in 2021.^[\[292\]](#cite_note-292)^ Vilnius has nine international schools, including the International School of Vilnius, [Vilnius International French Lyceum](/wiki/Vilnius_International_French_Lyceum "Vilnius International French Lyceum"), British International School of Vilnius, and American International School of Vilnius.^[\[293\]](#cite_note-293)^{#cite_ref-293}  

### Tertiary education {#Tertiary_education}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Tertiary education")\]
[![Old buildings and a church](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Vilnius_University_Great_Courtyard_2%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/220px-Vilnius_University_Great_Courtyard_2%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_University_Great_Courtyard_2,_Vilnius,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg) The Great Courtyard of [Vilnius University](/wiki/Vilnius_University "Vilnius University") and the [Church of St. Johns](/wiki/Church_of_St._Johns,_Vilnius "Church of St. Johns, Vilnius")

On 14 October 1773, the [Commission of National Education](/wiki/Commission_of_National_Education "Commission of National Education") (Lithuanian: *Edukacinė komisija* ) was created by the Sejm of the Polish--Lithuanian Commonwealth and Grand Duke Stanisław August Poniatowski, who supervised schools and Vilnius University in the Commonwealth. Because of its authority and autonomy, it is considered Europe's first [ministry](/wiki/Ministry_(government_department) "Ministry (government department)") of education and an example of the [Enlightenment in the Commonwealth](/wiki/Polish_Enlightenment "Polish Enlightenment").^[\[294\]](#cite_note-294)^{#cite_ref-294}

Vilnius has a number of universities, the largest and oldest of which is Vilnius University.^[\[295\]](#cite_note-Facts_and_Figures-295)^ With its main campus in the Old Town, it has been ranked among the top 500 universities in the world by [QS World University Rankings](/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings "QS World University Rankings").^[\[296\]](#cite_note-296)^ The university participates in projects with UNESCO and [NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO"). It has master's programs in English and Russian,^[\[297\]](#cite_note-297)^ and programs in cooperation with other universities throughout Europe. The university has 14 faculties.^[\[295\]](#cite_note-Facts_and_Figures-295)^{#cite_ref-Facts_and_Figures_295-1}

Other universities include [Mykolas Romeris University](/wiki/Mykolas_Romeris_University "Mykolas Romeris University"),^[\[298\]](#cite_note-298)^ Vilnius Gediminas Technical University^[\[299\]](#cite_note-299)^ and the [Lithuanian University of Educational Sciences](/wiki/Lithuanian_University_of_Educational_Sciences "Lithuanian University of Educational Sciences"), which merged with [Vytautas Magnus University](/wiki/Vytautas_Magnus_University "Vytautas Magnus University") in 2018.^[\[300\]](#cite_note-300)^ Specialized tertiary schools with university status include the [General Jonas Žemaitis Military Academy of Lithuania](/wiki/General_Jonas_%C5%BDemaitis_Military_Academy_of_Lithuania "General Jonas Žemaitis Military Academy of Lithuania"), the Lithuanian Academy of Music and Theatre, and the [Vilnius Academy of Arts](/wiki/Vilnius_Academy_of_Arts "Vilnius Academy of Arts"). The museum associated with the [Vilnius Academy of Arts](/wiki/Vilnius_Academy_of_Arts "Vilnius Academy of Arts") contains about 12,000 artworks.^[\[301\]](#cite_note-301)^{#cite_ref-301}  

### Libraries {#Libraries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Libraries")\]
[![A long, ornate reading room](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/VU_bibliotekos_Smuglevi%C4%8Diaus_sal%C4%97.JPG/220px-VU_bibliotekos_Smuglevi%C4%8Diaus_sal%C4%97.JPG)](/wiki/File:VU_bibliotekos_Smuglevi%C4%8Diaus_sal%C4%97.JPG) A 16th-century central [Vilnius University Library](/wiki/Vilnius_University_Library "Vilnius University Library") reading room, decorated in 1803 with portraits of the 12 most prominent figures in antiquity, art and science^[\[302\]](#cite_note-302)^

The Vilnius city municipality central library (Lithuanian: *Vilniaus miesto savivaldybės centrinė biblioteka* ) operates [public libraries](/wiki/Public_library "Public library") in the city.^[\[303\]](#cite_note-303)^ It has 16 branches, one (Saulutė) dedicated to [children's literature](/wiki/Children%27s_literature "Children's literature").^[\[304\]](#cite_note-304)^ Many libraries offer free [computer literacy](/wiki/Computer_literacy "Computer literacy") courses.^[\[305\]](#cite_note-305)^ The public libraries require a free LIBIS (integrated information system of Lithuanian libraries) card.^[\[306\]](#cite_note-306)^{#cite_ref-306}

The [Martynas Mažvydas National Library of Lithuania](/wiki/Martynas_Ma%C5%BEvydas_National_Library_of_Lithuania "Martynas Mažvydas National Library of Lithuania") (Lithuanian: *Lietuvos nacionalinė Martyno Mažvydo biblioteka* ) in Gediminas Avenue, founded in 1919, collects, organizes and preserves Lithuania's written cultural heritage, collects Lithuanian and foreign documents relevant to research and Lithuania's educational and cultural needs, and provides library services to the public.^[\[307\]](#cite_note-307)^ By 1 July 2019, its electronic catalog had 1,140,708 bibliographic records.^[\[308\]](#cite_note-308)^{#cite_ref-308}

The [Wroblewski Library of the Lithuanian Academy of Sciences](/wiki/Wroblewski_Library_of_the_Lithuanian_Academy_of_Sciences "Wroblewski Library of the Lithuanian Academy of Sciences") (Lithuanian: *Lietuvos mokslų akademijos Vrublevskių biblioteka* ) is open to all.^[\[309\]](#cite_note-mab-309)^ The library had 3,733,514 volumes by 1 January 2015, and 12,274 registered users.^[\[309\]](#cite_note-mab-309)^{#cite_ref-mab_309-1}

Every [Lithuanian university and college](/wiki/List_of_universities_and_colleges_in_Lithuania "List of universities and colleges in Lithuania") has a library for students, professors and [alumni](/wiki/Alumni "Alumni"). The [National Open Access Scientific Communication and Information Center](/wiki/Vilnius_University_Library#National_Open_Access_Scientific_Communication_and_Information_Center "Vilnius University Library") of Vilnius University (Lithuanian: *Vilniaus universiteto bibliotekos Mokslinės komunikacijos ir informacijos centras* ) in Saulėtekis Valley opened in 2013 and has over 800 workplaces in an area of 14,043.61 m^2^ (151,164.2 sq ft).^[\[310\]](#cite_note-310)^^[\[311\]](#cite_note-311)^ Central Vilnius University Library,^[\[312\]](#cite_note-312)^ Vilnius Gediminas Technical University Library, Mykolas Romeris University Library, ISM University of Management and Economics Library, European Humanities University Library, and Kazimieras Simonavičius University Library are on their respective campuses in Vilnius.^[\[313\]](#cite_note-313)^{#cite_ref-313}
