{#cite_ref-314} [![A small brick church, surrounded by trees](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/%C5%A0v._Mikalojaus_ba%C5%BEny%C4%8Dios_%C5%A1onas_2.jpg/220px-%C5%A0v._Mikalojaus_ba%C5%BEny%C4%8Dios_%C5%A1onas_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:%C5%A0v._Mikalojaus_ba%C5%BEny%C4%8Dios_%C5%A1onas_2.jpg) Vilnius' [Church of Saint Nicholas](/wiki/Church_of_Saint_Nicholas,_Vilnius "Church of Saint Nicholas, Vilnius"), built before 1387, is Lithuania's oldest surviving Catholic church.  
[![Exterior of a large, ornate, light-coloured church](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/St_Casimir_Church_Exterior_At_Dusk%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/220px-St_Casimir_Church_Exterior_At_Dusk%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg)](/wiki/File:St_Casimir_Church_Exterior_At_Dusk,_Vilnius,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg) The [Church of St. Casimir](/wiki/Church_of_St._Casimir,_Vilnius "Church of St. Casimir, Vilnius"), Vilnius' first Baroque church, is known for its [acoustics](/wiki/Acoustics "Acoustics") and [organ](/wiki/Organ_(music) "Organ (music)") concerts.

By the 17th century, Vilnius was known as a city of numerous religions. In 1600, Samuel Lewkenor's book about cities with universities was published in London;^[\[315\]](#cite_note-315)^ According to Lewkenor, Vilnius' population included Catholics, Orthodox, followers of John Calvin and Martin Luther, Jews and Tartar Muslims.^\[*[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources")*\]^{#cite_ref-315}

During that century, Vilnius had a reputation as a city unrivaled in Europe for its number and variety of churches. Robert Morden wrote in *Geography Rectified or a Description of the World* that no other city in the world could surpass Vilnius in the number of churches and temples except, perhaps, Amsterdam.^[\[316\]](#cite_note-316)^^[\[317\]](#cite_note-317)^{#cite_ref-317}

Vilnius is the seat of the [Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Vilnius](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Vilnius "Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Vilnius"), housing major church institutions and the archdiocesan Vilnius Cathedral. A number of Christian [beatified](/wiki/Beatification "Beatification") people, [martyrs](/wiki/Martyr#Christianity "Martyr"), [servants of God](/wiki/Servant_of_God "Servant of God") and [saints](/wiki/Saint "Saint") are associated with the city. They include the [Franciscan martyrs of Vilnius](/wiki/Franciscan_martyrs_of_Vilnius "Franciscan martyrs of Vilnius"), the Orthodox martyrs [Anthony, John, and Eustathius](/wiki/Anthony,_John,_and_Eustathius "Anthony, John, and Eustathius"), Saint Casimir, [Josaphat Kuntsevych](/wiki/Josaphat_Kuntsevych "Josaphat Kuntsevych"), [Andrew Bobola](/wiki/Andrew_Bobola "Andrew Bobola"), [Raphael Kalinowski](/wiki/Raphael_Kalinowski "Raphael Kalinowski"), [Faustina Kowalska](/wiki/Faustina_Kowalska "Faustina Kowalska"), and [Jurgis Matulaitis-Matulevičius](/wiki/Jurgis_Matulaitis-Matulevi%C4%8Dius "Jurgis Matulaitis-Matulevičius"). There are a number of Roman Catholic churches in the city, small monasteries, and religious schools. Church architecture includes Gothic, Renaissance, Baroque and [neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") styles, with examples of each in the Old Town. [Eastern Rite Catholicism](/wiki/Eastern_Catholic_Churches "Eastern Catholic Churches") has also had a presence in Vilnius since the [Union of Brest](/wiki/Union_of_Brest "Union of Brest"). The Baroque Basilian Gate is part of an Eastern Rite monastery.
[![A large white church against a blue sky](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Russian_Orthodox_Church_of_The_Holy_Mother_of_God_Vilnius_%285990381200%29.jpg/220px-Russian_Orthodox_Church_of_The_Holy_Mother_of_God_Vilnius_%285990381200%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Russian_Orthodox_Church_of_The_Holy_Mother_of_God_Vilnius_(5990381200).jpg) The Orthodox [Cathedral of the Theotokos](/wiki/Cathedral_of_the_Theotokos,_Vilnius "Cathedral of the Theotokos, Vilnius"), built in the 14th century by Grand Duke [Algirdas](/wiki/Algirdas "Algirdas") for [Ruthenians](/wiki/Ruthenians "Ruthenians") in the city's Ruthenian quarter^[\[318\]](#cite_note-Darius-318)^

Vilnius has had an [Eastern Orthodox](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox "Eastern Orthodox") presence since the 12th century, and the [Russian Orthodox](/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church "Russian Orthodox Church") [Monastery of the Holy Spirit](/wiki/Orthodox_Church_of_the_Holy_Spirit,_Vilnius "Orthodox Church of the Holy Spirit, Vilnius") is near the \[Gate of Dawn. [St. Paraskeva's Orthodox Church](/wiki/Church_of_St._Paraskeva,_Vilnius "Church of St. Paraskeva, Vilnius") in the Old Town was the site of the 1705 [baptism](/wiki/Baptism "Baptism") of [Hannibal](/wiki/Abram_Petrovich_Gannibal "Abram Petrovich Gannibal"), the great-grandfather of [Alexander Pushkin](/wiki/Alexander_Pushkin "Alexander Pushkin"), by Tsar [Peter the Great](/wiki/Peter_the_Great "Peter the Great"). Many [Old Believers](/wiki/Old_Believers "Old Believers"), who split from the Russian Orthodox Church in 1667, settled in Lithuania; a Supreme Council of Old Believers is based in Vilnius. The Orthodox [Church of St. Constantine and St. Michael](/wiki/Church_of_St._Constantine_and_St._Michael "Church of St. Constantine and St. Michael") was built in 1913. A number of Protestant and other Christian denominations^[\[319\]](#cite_note-319)^ are represented in Vilnius, notably [Lutheran](/wiki/Lutheranism "Lutheranism") Evangelicals and [Baptists](/wiki/Baptists "Baptists").{#cite_ref-319}

Lithuania's pre-Christian religion, centred on the forces of nature and personified by deities such as [Perkūnas](/wiki/Perk%C5%ABnas "Perkūnas") (the thunder god), is experiencing increased interest. [Romuva](/wiki/Romuva_(religion) "Romuva (religion)") established a Vilnius branch in 1991.^[\[320\]](#cite_note-320)^{#cite_ref-320}  

### Judaism and Karaism {#Judaism_and_Karaism}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Judaism and Karaism")\]  
See also: [History of the Jews in Lithuania](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Lithuania "History of the Jews in Lithuania")
[![Large, cream-coloured synagogue](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Vilniaus_sinagoga.jpg/220px-Vilniaus_sinagoga.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilniaus_sinagoga.jpg) The [Choral Synagogue](/wiki/Choral_Synagogue_(Vilnius) "Choral Synagogue (Vilnius)")

Known as "Yerushalayim D'Lita" (the Jerusalem of Lithuania), Vilnius had been a world centre for [Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah") study and had a large Jewish population since the 18th century. A major scholar of Judaism and the [Kabbalah](/wiki/Kabbalah "Kabbalah") was Rabbi Eliyahu Kremer, known as the [Vilna Gaon](/wiki/Vilna_Gaon "Vilna Gaon"), whose writings significantly influence Orthodox Jews. The [Vilna Shas](/wiki/Vilna_Edition_Shas "Vilna Edition Shas"), the most widely used version of the [Talmud](/wiki/Talmud "Talmud"), was published in the city in 1886.^[\[321\]](#cite_note-321)^ Jewish life in Vilnius was destroyed during the Holocaust, and a memorial stone dedicated to victims of [Nazi](/wiki/Nazism "Nazism") genocide is in the centre of the former [Jewish Ghetto](/wiki/Vilna_Ghetto "Vilna Ghetto") on present-day Mėsinių Street. The [Vilna Gaon Museum of Jewish History](/wiki/Vilna_Gaon_Museum_of_Jewish_History "Vilna Gaon Museum of Jewish History") is dedicated to the history of Lithuanian Jewish life. The site of [Vilnius's largest synagogue](/wiki/Great_Synagogue_of_Vilna "Great Synagogue of Vilna"), built in the early 1630s, destroyed by Nazi Germany during its [occupation of Lithuania](/wiki/German_occupation_of_Lithuania_during_World_War_II "German occupation of Lithuania during World War II") and later demolished by Soviet authorities, was found by [ground-penetrating radar](/wiki/Ground-penetrating_radar "Ground-penetrating radar") in June 2015.^[\[322\]](#cite_note-322)^ Archaeologists began excavating the site in 2016, and that work continues as of July 2024.^[\[323\]](#cite_note-323)^{#cite_ref-323}

The [Karaites](/wiki/Karaite_Judaism "Karaite Judaism") are a Jewish sect who migrated to Lithuania from the Crimea. Small in numbers, they have become more prominent since Lithuanian independence and have restored their [kenesas](/wiki/Kenesa "Kenesa") (including the [Vilnius Kenesa](/wiki/Vilnius_Kenesa "Vilnius Kenesa")).^[\[324\]](#cite_note-324)^{#cite_ref-324}  

### Pilgrimage sites {#Pilgrimage}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Pilgrimage sites")\]
> It is safe to say that I have been in Vilnius all my life, at least since I became conscious. I was in Vilnius with thoughts and heart -- one could say \[my\] whole being. And so it stayed -- and in Rome.  
> --- [Pope John Paul II](/wiki/Pope_John_Paul_II "Pope John Paul II") at the [Dominican Church of the Holy Spirit](/wiki/Dominican_Church_of_the_Holy_Spirit "Dominican Church of the Holy Spirit") during his 1993 visit to Lithuania^[\[325\]](#cite_note-325)^
[![An ornate Baroque chapel](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Our_Lady_of_the_Gate_of_Dawn_Interior_During_Service%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg/220px-Our_Lady_of_the_Gate_of_Dawn_Interior_During_Service%2C_Vilnius%2C_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg)](/wiki/File:Our_Lady_of_the_Gate_of_Dawn_Interior_During_Service,_Vilnius,_Lithuania_-_Diliff.jpg) Interior of the Chapel of the [Gate of Dawn](/wiki/Gate_of_Dawn "Gate of Dawn"), with its eponymous painting

Since the 1387 Christianization of Lithuania, Vilnius has become a centre of Christianity in the country and a [pilgrimage](/wiki/Christian_pilgrimage "Christian pilgrimage") site. The Vilnius Pilgrimage Centre (Lithuanian: *Vilniaus piligrimų centras* ) coordinates pilgrimages, assists with their preparation, and performs pilgrimage pastoral care.^[\[326\]](#cite_note-326)^ A number of places in Vilnius are associated with [miracles](/wiki/Miracles_in_Christianity "Miracles in Christianity") or mark events significant to Christians, and the Chapel of the Gate of Dawn is visited by thousands of Christian pilgrims annually. The gates were initially part of the defensive Wall of Vilnius; they were given to the [Carmelites](/wiki/Carmelites "Carmelites") in the 16th century, who installed a [chapel](/wiki/Chapel "Chapel") in the gates with a 17th-century Catholic painting: *[Our Lady of the Gate of Dawn](/wiki/Our_Lady_of_the_Gate_of_Dawn "Our Lady of the Gate of Dawn")* . The painting was later decorated with [gold-plated silver](/wiki/Riza "Riza") and is associated with miracles and a legend.^[\[327\]](#cite_note-pilgrimage-327)^{#cite_ref-pilgrimage_327-0}
[![A painting of Jesus](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Divine_Mercy_Sanctuary_in_Vilnius4.JPG/180px-Divine_Mercy_Sanctuary_in_Vilnius4.JPG)](/wiki/File:Divine_Mercy_Sanctuary_in_Vilnius4.JPG) The first Divine Mercy painting by [Eugeniusz Kazimirowski](/wiki/Eugeniusz_Kazimirowski "Eugeniusz Kazimirowski") (1934) at the [Divine Mercy Sanctuary](/wiki/Sanctuary_of_the_Divine_Mercy,_Vilnius "Sanctuary of the Divine Mercy, Vilnius")

The [Sanctuary of the Divine Mercy](/wiki/Sanctuary_of_the_Divine_Mercy,_Vilnius "Sanctuary of the Divine Mercy, Vilnius") is a pilgrimage site which has a [Divine Mercy image](/wiki/Divine_Mercy_image "Divine Mercy image"). Vilnius was the birthplace of the [Divine Mercy devotion](/wiki/Divine_Mercy_(Catholic_devotion) "Divine Mercy (Catholic devotion)") when Saint [Faustina Kowalska](/wiki/Faustina_Kowalska "Faustina Kowalska") began her mission under the guidance of [Michał Sopoćko](/wiki/Micha%C5%82_Sopo%C4%87ko "Michał Sopoćko"), her [spiritual director](/wiki/Spiritual_director "Spiritual director"). The first Divine Mercy image was painted in 1934 by [Eugeniusz Kazimirowski](/wiki/Eugeniusz_Kazimirowski "Eugeniusz Kazimirowski") under the supervision of Kowalska, and it hangs in the Divine Mercy Sanctuary in Vilnius. Adoration of the [Blessed Sacrament](/wiki/Blessed_Sacrament "Blessed Sacrament") takes place in the shrine around the clock.^[\[327\]](#cite_note-pilgrimage-327)^ The House of St. Faustina, in Antakalnis' V. Grybo Street, is open to pilgrims.^[\[328\]](#cite_note-328)^{#cite_ref-328}

The [Church of St. Philip and St. Jacob](/wiki/Church_of_St._Philip_and_St._Jacob,_Vilnius "Church of St. Philip and St. Jacob, Vilnius"), near Lukiškės Square, has the painting of the Mother of God of Lukiškės which has reportedly attracted miracles.^[\[327\]](#cite_note-pilgrimage-327)^ The [icon](/wiki/Icon "Icon"), painted in the 15th or 16th century, is one of the country's oldest examples of [easel](/wiki/Easel "Easel") painting.^[\[329\]](#cite_note-329)^ It was brought by Grand Duchy of Lithuania artillery general Motiejus Korvinas Gosievskis from the Russo-Polish War. Since 1684, miracles have been reported at the Vilnius Dominican monastery related to the image which were published in a 1737 book, *Mystical Fountain* (Lithuanian: *Mistinis fontanas* ). The icon was restored and returned to the [Dominicans](/wiki/Dominican_Order "Dominican Order") in 2012.^[\[330\]](#cite_note-330)^{#cite_ref-330}

[Three Crosses](/wiki/Three_Crosses "Three Crosses") is a monument in the city. According to a legend in the *[Bychowiec Chronicle](/wiki/Bychowiec_Chronicle "Bychowiec Chronicle")* , fourteen [Franciscan](/wiki/Franciscan "Franciscan") friars were invited to Vilnius from [Podolia](/wiki/Podolia "Podolia") by [Petras Goštautas](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petras_Go%C5%A1tautas_(1305) "lt:Petras Goštautas (1305)").^[\[331\]](#cite_note-gidzi-331)^ The friars preached the [gospel](/wiki/Gospel "Gospel") and denigrated pagan Lithuanian gods; angry city residents burned the monastery and killed the fourteen friars. Seven were beheaded on Bleak Hill, and the other seven were [crucified](/wiki/Crucifixion "Crucifixion") and thrown into the Neris or Vilnia.^[\[331\]](#cite_note-gidzi-331)^{#cite_ref-gidzi_331-1}
[![Painting of a church at the top of many steps](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Khrutsky_Vilnius_Calvary.jpg/220px-Khrutsky_Vilnius_Calvary.jpg)](/wiki/File:Khrutsky_Vilnius_Calvary.jpg) Verkiai Calvary 1840s, built in gratitude for victory in the Second Northern War

[Verkiai Calvary](/wiki/Verkiai_Calvary "Verkiai Calvary") (or Vilnius Calvary), Lithuania's second-oldest [calvary](/wiki/Calvary_(sanctuary) "Calvary (sanctuary)"), is in the neighborhood of [Verkiai](/wiki/Verkiai "Verkiai"). The calvary was built from 1662 to 1669 in gratitude for victory in the [Second Northern War](/wiki/Second_Northern_War "Second Northern War") (1655--60).^[\[332\]](#cite_note-332)^ The consecration ceremony of the [Stations of the Cross](/wiki/Stations_of_the_Cross "Stations of the Cross") took place for [Pentecost](/wiki/Pentecost "Pentecost") on 9 June 1669.^[\[333\]](#cite_note-333)^ The calvary includes 20 brick chapels, seven wooden gates and a brick one, and a bridge with a wood chapel.^[\[334\]](#cite_note-334)^ The path ends at the [Church of the Discovery of the Holy Cross](/wiki/Church_of_the_Discovery_of_the_Holy_Cross,_Vilnius "Church of the Discovery of the Holy Cross, Vilnius"). All the chapels except the four closest to the church were destroyed by Soviet authorities overnight with [dynamite](/wiki/Dynamite "Dynamite") in 1962. The calvary was reconstructed from 1990 to 2002, and the chapels were consecrated on Pentecost in 2002.^[\[335\]](#cite_note-335)^ Pilgrimages to the calvary are organized regularly with the clergy.^[\[336\]](#cite_note-336)^{#cite_ref-336}

The Church Heritage Museum (Lithuanian: *Bažnytinio paveldo muziejus* ) contains city's the oldest and largest collection of liturgical artefacts in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Vilnius.^[\[327\]](#cite_note-pilgrimage-327)^^[\[337\]](#cite_note-337)^ Vilnius is the only city in the Baltic states with an [Apostolic Nunciature](/wiki/Apostolic_Nunciature_to_Lithuania "Apostolic Nunciature to Lithuania"), where Pope John Paul II and [Pope Francis](/wiki/Pope_Francis "Pope Francis") stayed during their visits to Lithuania, [Latvia](/wiki/Latvia "Latvia") and [Estonia](/wiki/Estonia "Estonia").^[\[338\]](#cite_note-338)^{#cite_ref-338}  

Parks, squares and cemeteries {#Parks.2C_squares_and_cemeteries}
----------------------------------------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: Parks, squares and cemeteries")\]
[![Three white stone crosses, surrounded by vegetation](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Vilnius_Three_Crosses.jpg/220px-Vilnius_Three_Crosses.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_Three_Crosses.jpg) The [Three Crosses](/wiki/Three_Crosses "Three Crosses") in [Kalnai Park](/wiki/Kalnai_Park "Kalnai Park")

Almost half of Vilnius is covered by green space such as parks, public gardens, and nature reserves. The city has a number of lakes where residents and visitors swim and barbecue in the summer. Thirty lakes and 16 rivers cover 2.1 percent of Vilnius' area, some of which have sand beaches.

Vingis Park, the city's largest, hosted several large rallies during Lithuania's drive towards independence in the 1980s. Sections of the annual [Vilnius Marathon](/wiki/Vilnius_Marathon "Vilnius Marathon") are on public walkways along the Neris. The green area next to the White Bridge is a popular place to enjoy good weather, and has become a venue for several musical and film events.
[![Aerial view of a large square](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Lukiskiu_aikste_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg/220px-Lukiskiu_aikste_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lukiskiu_aikste_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg) Lukiškės Square

[Cathedral Square](/wiki/Cathedral_Square,_Vilnius "Cathedral Square, Vilnius") in the Old Town is surrounded by a number of the city's most historic sites. [Lukiškės Square](/wiki/Luki%C5%A1k%C4%97s_Square "Lukiškės Square") is the largest, bordered by several government buildings: the [Lithuanian Ministry of Foreign Affairs](/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Lithuania) "Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Lithuania)"), Ministry of Finance, Polish Embassy and the [Genocide Victims' Museum](/wiki/Museum_of_Occupations_and_Freedom_Fights "Museum of Occupations and Freedom Fights"), where the [KGB](/wiki/KGB "KGB") tortured and killed opponents of the communist regime. A large statue of [Vladimir Lenin](/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin "Vladimir Lenin") in its centre was removed in 1991.^[\[339\]](#cite_note-339)^ Town Hall Square has been a centre of trade fairs, celebrations and events, including the [Kaziukas Fair](/wiki/Kaziuko_mug%C4%97 "Kaziuko mugė"). The city's Christmas tree is displayed there. State ceremonies are often held in [Daukanto Square](/wiki/Daukanto_Square "Daukanto Square"), facing the Presidential Palace.{#cite_ref-339}
[![Aerial view of a large green area with many trees](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Bernardinu_sodas_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg/220px-Bernardinu_sodas_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bernardinu_sodas_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg) Bernardinai Garden

[Bernardinai Garden](/wiki/Bernardinai_Garden "Bernardinai Garden"), near [Gediminas Tower](/wiki/Gediminas%27_Tower "Gediminas' Tower") (previously known as Sereikiškės Park), opened on 20 October 2013 after it was restored to its 19th-century Vladislovas Štrausas environment.^[\[340\]](#cite_note-340)^ It is a venue for concerts, festivals, and exhibitions. [Chiune Sugihara](/wiki/Chiune_Sugihara "Chiune Sugihara") [Sakura](/wiki/Sakura "Sakura") Park was established in 2001, and a [Japanese garden](/wiki/Japanese_garden "Japanese garden") (both in Šnipiškės) was opened in 2023.^[\[341\]](#cite_note-341)^^[\[342\]](#cite_note-342)^{#cite_ref-342}

[Rasos Cemetery](/wiki/Rasos_Cemetery "Rasos Cemetery"), consecrated in 1801, is the burial site of [Jonas Basanavičius](/wiki/Jonas_Basanavi%C4%8Dius "Jonas Basanavičius") and other [signatories of the 1918 Act of Independence](/wiki/Signatories_of_the_Act_of_Independence_of_Lithuania "Signatories of the Act of Independence of Lithuania") and the heart of Polish leader [Józef Piłsudski](/wiki/J%C3%B3zef_Pi%C5%82sudski "Józef Piłsudski"). Two of the city's three [Jewish cemeteries](/wiki/Jewish_cemeteries_of_Vilnius "Jewish cemeteries of Vilnius") were destroyed by communist authorities during the Soviet era, and the remains in the Vilna Gaon were moved to the remaining one. A monument was erected at the site of Užupis Old Jewish Cemetery was.^[\[343\]](#cite_note-343)^ The [Bernardine Cemetery](/wiki/Bernardine_Cemetery "Bernardine Cemetery"), established in 1810, has about 18,000 burials; closed during the 1970s, it is being restored. [Antakalnis Cemetery](/wiki/Antakalnis_Cemetery "Antakalnis Cemetery"), established in 1809, has memorials to Polish, Lithuanian, German and Russian soldiers and the graves of those who were killed during the January Events.{#cite_ref-343}  

Tourism {#Tourism}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: Tourism")\]
[![A group of tourists in cool weather](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Tourism_has_certainly_reached_Vilnius_-_Old_Town%2C_Sept._2008_%282937998142%29.jpg/220px-Tourism_has_certainly_reached_Vilnius_-_Old_Town%2C_Sept._2008_%282937998142%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tourism_has_certainly_reached_Vilnius_-_Old_Town,_Sept._2008_(2937998142).jpg) Tourists in the Old Town [![Aerial view of an urban neighborhood with some trees](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Uzupis_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg/220px-Uzupis_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg)](/wiki/File:Uzupis_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg) [Užupis](/wiki/U%C5%BEupis "Užupis"), a self-proclaimed republic, has [Bohemian](/wiki/Bohemianism "Bohemianism") culture and art.

According to [Lithuanian Department of Statistics](/wiki/Lithuanian_Department_of_Statistics "Lithuanian Department of Statistics"), 1,200,858 visitors rented rooms in Vilnius in 2018 and spent a total of 2,212,109 nights there; this was a respective increase of 12 percent and 11 percent over the previous year.^[\[344\]](#cite_note-tourism2018-344)^ Eighty-one percent of the visitors were foreigners (970,577), 11 percent more than in 2017. Most foreign visitors (47 percent) came from Belarus (102,915), [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany") (101,999), Poland (99,386), Russia (90,388) and Latvia (61,829).^[\[344\]](#cite_note-tourism2018-344)^ Nineteen percent of the guests were Lithuanian, 18 percent more than in 2017.^[\[344\]](#cite_note-tourism2018-344)^{#cite_ref-tourism2018_344-2}

A 2018 Vilnius visitor survey reported that 48 percent were visiting the city for the first time, 85 percent of tourists planned the trip by themselves, and 15 percent used a travel agency.^[\[345\]](#cite_note-345)^ Forty percent said that they visited Vilnius to learn about the city's history and heritage, with 23 percent also planning trips to other parts of Lithuania.^[\[346\]](#cite_note-346)^ Many Belarusians (about 200,000 [travel visas](/wiki/Travel_visa "Travel visa") annually) visit the city's [shopping malls](/wiki/Shopping_mall "Shopping mall") and submit half-meter-long receipts to [customs](/wiki/Customs "Customs") officials.^[\[347\]](#cite_note-347)^{#cite_ref-347}

Vilnius' Tourist Information Centres were visited by 119,136 visitors in 2018 (95,932 foreigners and 23,204 Lithuanians), a five-percent increase over 2017.^[\[344\]](#cite_note-tourism2018-344)^ The city's highest-rated tourist services are restaurants ([cafés](/wiki/Caf%C3%A9 "Café")), old-town attractions, hotels or other accommodations, trips to [Trakai](/wiki/Trakai "Trakai"), parks and other green zones, connections to [Vilnius Airport](/wiki/Vilnius_Airport "Vilnius Airport"), and food in hotels, restaurants and cafés.^[\[348\]](#cite_note-348)^ Vilnius is one of a few European capitals which allows [hot air ballooning](/wiki/Hot_air_ballooning "Hot air ballooning") through the city, with nearly 1,000 trips in 2022.^[\[349\]](#cite_note-349)^ In the City Costs Barometer 2019, Vilnius was ranked number one of European capitals for offering the best value to visitors.^[\[350\]](#cite_note-350)^ The controversial [Vilnius Palace of Concerts and Sports](/wiki/Vilnius_Palace_of_Concerts_and_Sports "Vilnius Palace of Concerts and Sports"), built by Soviet authorities on the site of a Jewish graveyard, was scheduled to become the leading convention center in the Baltic states in 2022.^[\[351\]](#cite_note-351)^{#cite_ref-351}  

### Hotels {#Hotels}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Hotels")\]
[![Exterior of a large, old building](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Kempinski_Hotel_Cathedral_Square_Vilnius.jpg/220px-Kempinski_Hotel_Cathedral_Square_Vilnius.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kempinski_Hotel_Cathedral_Square_Vilnius.jpg) The Kempinski Hotel

Lithuania is a member of the [European Hotelstars Union](/wiki/Hotel_rating#European_Hotelstars_Union "Hotel rating").^[\[352\]](#cite_note-352)^ Vilnius has six [five-star hotels](/wiki/Hotel_rating "Hotel rating"), all in the Old Town,^[\[353\]](#cite_note-353)^ and 27 four-star hotels.^[\[354\]](#cite_note-354)^ The [Kempinski](/wiki/Kempinski "Kempinski") Hotel, with a view of Cathedral Square, is considered the city's most luxurious hotel.^[\[355\]](#cite_note-imf-355)^^[\[356\]](#cite_note-356)^{#cite_ref-356}

According to a 2018 Vilnius visitors' survey, 44 percent stayed in mid-range hotels (three or four stars), 12 percent stayed in standard or economy hotels (one or two stars) and 11 percent stayed in five-star hotels.^[\[357\]](#cite_note-357)^ The city had 82 hotels, eight motels and 40 other accommodation facilities in 2019, with 6,822 rooms and 15,248 beds. The highest hotel-room occupancy was in August, and the lowest was in February.^[\[344\]](#cite_note-tourism2018-344)^{#cite_ref-tourism2018_344-4}  

Sports {#Sports}
----------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: Sports")\]
[![A large group of young people in green T-shirts](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Vilnius_Marathon_2015_volunteers_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg/220px-Vilnius_Marathon_2015_volunteers_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_Marathon_2015_volunteers_by_Augustas_Didzgalvis.jpg) 2015 Vilnius Marathon volunteers [![Downtown spectators, on foot and on bicycles](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Beach_Volley_in_Vilnius.jpg/220px-Beach_Volley_in_Vilnius.jpg)](/wiki/File:Beach_Volley_in_Vilnius.jpg) The 2024 CEV Beach Volley Nations Cup tournament was held in the central business district.^[\[358\]](#cite_note-358)^

Several basketball teams are based in the city. [BC Wolves](/wiki/BC_Wolves "BC Wolves") began competing in the [2022--23 season](/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_LKL_season "2022–23 LKL season") of the [Lithuanian Basketball League](/wiki/Lietuvos_krep%C5%A1inio_lyga "Lietuvos krepšinio lyga") (LKL). The largest team is [BC Rytas](/wiki/BC_Rytas "BC Rytas"), who participates in the international [Basketball Champions League](/wiki/Basketball_Champions_League "Basketball Champions League") (BCL) and the LKL; they won the ULEB Cup (predecessor to the [EuroCup](/wiki/EuroCup_Basketball "EuroCup Basketball")) in [2005](/wiki/2004%E2%80%9305_ULEB_Cup "2004–05 ULEB Cup") and the EuroCup in [2009](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_Eurocup_Basketball "2008–09 Eurocup Basketball"). Their home arena is the 2,500-seat [Jeep Arena](/wiki/Jeep_Arena "Jeep Arena"); all European matches and important domestic matches are played at the 10,000-seat [Twinsbet Arena](/wiki/Twinsbet_Arena "Twinsbet Arena").

Vilnius also has several football teams; [FK Žalgiris](/wiki/FK_%C5%BDalgiris "FK Žalgiris"), the main team, plays at the 5,000-seat [LFF Stadium](/wiki/LFF_Stadium "LFF Stadium").^[\[359\]](#cite_note-359)^ The multi-use [Lithuania National Stadium](/wiki/Lithuania_National_Stadium "Lithuania National Stadium") is under construction. The 28-court [SEB Arena](/wiki/SEB_Arena "SEB Arena") is the largest [tennis](/wiki/Tennis "Tennis") complex in [central Europe](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe") and home of the Lithuanian tennis and [squash](/wiki/Squash_(sport) "Squash (sport)") teams.^[\[360\]](#cite_note-360)^{#cite_ref-360}

[Olympic](/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games "Summer Olympic Games") swimming champions [Lina Kačiušytė](/wiki/Lina_Ka%C4%8Diu%C5%A1yt%C4%97 "Lina Kačiušytė") and [Robertas Žulpa](/wiki/Robertas_%C5%BDulpa "Robertas Žulpa") are from Vilnius. The city has several public [swimming pools](/wiki/Swimming_pool "Swimming pool"), with the Lazdynai Swimming Pool the only [Olympic-size swimming pool](/wiki/Olympic-size_swimming_pool "Olympic-size swimming pool").^[\[361\]](#cite_note-361)^ Vilnius is home to the Lithuanian [Bandy](/wiki/Bandy "Bandy") Association, Badminton Federation, Canoeing Sports Federation, Baseball Association, Biathlon Federation, Sailors Union, Football Federation, Fencing Federation, Cycling Sports Federation, Archery Federation, Athletics Federation, Ice Hockey Federation, Basketball Federation, Curling Federation, Rowing Federation, Wrestling Federation, Speed Skating Association, Gymnastics Federation, Equestrian Union, Modern Pentathlon Federation, Shooting Union, Triathlon Federation, Volleyball Federation, Tennis Union, Taekwondo Federation, Weightlifting Federation, Table Tennis Association, Skiing Association, Rugby Federation, and Swimming Federation.^[\[362\]](#cite_note-362)^ The annual international [Vilnius Marathon](/wiki/Vilnius_Marathon "Vilnius Marathon") has thousands of participants.^[\[363\]](#cite_note-363)^{#cite_ref-363}  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=46 "Edit section: Transport")\]
[![A large, white building, seen from a parking lot](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Vilnius_Airport_main_entrance.jpg/220px-Vilnius_Airport_main_entrance.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilnius_Airport_main_entrance.jpg) Vilnius Airport main entrance

Navigability of the Neris is limited; no regular water routes exist, although it was used for transport in the past.^[\[364\]](#cite_note-364)^ [Vilnius Airport](/wiki/Vilnius_Airport "Vilnius Airport"), Lithuania's largest, serves about 50 cities in 25 countries.^[\[365\]](#cite_note-365)^ The airport, 5 km (3.1 mi) from the city centre, has a direct link to the [Vilnius railway station](/wiki/Vilnius_railway_station "Vilnius railway station"). The station is a rail hub with direct passenger service to Minsk, [Kaliningrad](/wiki/Kaliningrad "Kaliningrad"), [Moscow](/wiki/Moscow "Moscow") and [Saint Petersburg](/wiki/Saint_Petersburg "Saint Petersburg"), and is part of the [Pan-European Corridor IX](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_IX "Pan-European Corridor IX")'s Branch B.{#cite_ref-365}

Vilnius is the starting point of the [A1](/wiki/A1_highway_(Lithuania) "A1 highway (Lithuania)") motorway which runs across Lithuania, connecting its three major cities (Vilnius, Kaunas and [Klaipėda](/wiki/Klaip%C4%97da "Klaipėda")), and is part of [European route E85](/wiki/European_route_E85 "European route E85"). The [A2](/wiki/A2_highway_(Lithuania) "A2 highway (Lithuania)"), connecting Vilnius and [Panevėžys](/wiki/Panev%C4%97%C5%BEys "Panevėžys"), is part of the [E272](/wiki/European_route_E272 "European route E272"). Other highways out of the city include the [A3](/wiki/A3_highway_(Lithuania) "A3 highway (Lithuania)"), [A4](/wiki/A4_highway_(Lithuania) "A4 highway (Lithuania)"), [A14](/wiki/A14_highway_(Lithuania) "A14 highway (Lithuania)"), [A15](/wiki/A15_highway_(Lithuania) "A15 highway (Lithuania)"), and [A16](/wiki/A16_highway_(Lithuania) "A16 highway (Lithuania)"). Vilnius' southern bypass is the [A19](/wiki/A10_highway_(Lithuania) "A10 highway (Lithuania)").  

### Bus service {#Public_transport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Bus service")\]

The bus and [trolleybus](/wiki/Trolleybuses_in_Vilnius "Trolleybuses in Vilnius") networks are operated by Vilniaus viešasis transportas. There are over 60 bus, 18 trolleybus, six rapid bus and one night bus routes.^[\[366\]](#cite_note-366)^^[\[367\]](#cite_note-367)^ The trolleybus network is one of Europe's most extensive; over 250 buses and 260 trolleybuses transport about 500,000 passengers every workday.^[\[368\]](#cite_note-368)^ The first bus routes were established in 1926, and the first trolleybuses were introduced in 1956.^[\[369\]](#cite_note-369)^{#cite_ref-369}

At the end of 2007, an electronic monthly ticket system was introduced in which passengers could buy an electronic card in shops and newsstands and load it with money; monthly e-ticket cards could also be loaded over the Internet. Paper monthly tickets were in use until August 2008.^[\[370\]](#cite_note-370)^ On 15 August 2012, e-cards were replaced by Vilnius Citizen Cards (Vilniečio Kortelė) which could be purchased at newsstands and loaded with money and ticket type. Single-trip tickets have been replaced by 30- and 60-minute tickets. In 2014, a mobile app was introduced for public-transport tickets.^[\[371\]](#cite_note-371)^{#cite_ref-371}

Buses are low-floor [Volvo](/wiki/Volvo_Buses "Volvo Buses") and [Mercedes-Benz buses](/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_buses "Mercedes-Benz buses"), and trolleybuses are manufactured by [Solaris](/wiki/Solaris_Bus_%26_Coach "Solaris Bus & Coach"). Older [Škoda](/wiki/%C5%A0koda_Works "Škoda Works") vehicles, built in the Czech Republic and many refurbished, are still in service. In 2004, a contract was signed with Volvo Buses to purchase 90 new 7700 buses over a three-year period.^[\[372\]](#cite_note-372)^{#cite_ref-372}

In 2017, Vilnius began the largest upgrade of its bus service by purchasing 250 new low-floor buses. Sixty percent of the city's public buses were new by mid-2018, with free Wi-Fi and chargers for electronic devices.^[\[373\]](#cite_note-373)^ On 5 September 2017, 50 new [Isuzu](/wiki/Isuzu "Isuzu") buses were introduced.^[\[374\]](#cite_note-374)^ Vilnius City Municipality accepted bids for 41 new [trolleybuses](/wiki/Trolleybus "Trolleybus"); Solaris contracted to provide the trolleybuses by autumn 2018, with free Wi-Fi and chargers.^[\[375\]](#cite_note-375)^ On 13 November of that year, the municipality signed a contract with Solaris for the remaining 150 fourth-generation [Solaris Urbino](/wiki/Solaris_Urbino "Solaris Urbino") buses (100 standard and 50 [articulated](/wiki/Articulated_bus "Articulated bus")) with free Wi-Fi and USB charging.^[\[376\]](#cite_note-376)^ Five [electric](/wiki/Battery_electric_vehicle "Battery electric vehicle") [Karsan](/wiki/Karsan "Karsan") Jest Electric buses were introduced on 20 September 2019 for the number 89 route's narrow streets.^[\[377\]](#cite_note-377)^{#cite_ref-377}

Since 2017, a 30-minute ticket costs [€](/wiki/Euro "Euro")0.65; a 60-minute ticket costs €0.90, and a single ticket bought on board costs €1.00. Short- and long-term tickets and discounts for students and the elderly are available.^[\[378\]](#cite_note-378)^{#cite_ref-378}

[Vilnius Metro](/wiki/Vilnius_Metro "Vilnius Metro") and an electric tram have been proposed.^[\[379\]](#cite_note-379)^ In 2018, the Seimas and the president approved a metro project.^[\[380\]](#cite_note-380)^{#cite_ref-380}

Healthcare {#Healthcare}
------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=48 "Edit section: Healthcare")\]

When Vilnius was part of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, the city had [public bathhouses](/wiki/Public_bathhouse "Public bathhouse"); one-fourth the city's houses had individual bathhouses, and almost half had alcohol distilleries.^[\[381\]](#cite_note-381)^ In 1518, doctor and [canon](/wiki/Canon_(priest) "Canon (priest)") Martynas Dušnickis established the first *špitolė* in Vilnius: Lithuania's first hospital-like institution which treated people unable to care for themselves due to health, age, or poverty.^[\[382\]](#cite_note-382)^{#cite_ref-382}

The [Brotherhood of Saint Roch](/wiki/Brotherhood_of_Saint_Roch "Brotherhood of Saint Roch") maintained basic hospitals and shelters for the sick and disabled in Vilnius from 1708 to 1799, although it is unknown if the brothers had any medical education. They hired [paramedics](/wiki/Paramedic "Paramedic"), doctors, [surgeons](/wiki/Surgeon "Surgeon"), and female [nurses](/wiki/Nurse "Nurse") for female patients. A significant number of patients had [sexually transmitted diseases](/wiki/Sexually_transmitted_diseases "Sexually transmitted diseases") which other Catholic hospitals refused to treat. The brotherhood sheltered pregnant women, [abandoned children](/wiki/Abandoned_children "Abandoned children") and patients with injuries, [tuberculosis](/wiki/Tuberculosis "Tuberculosis"), [rheumatism](/wiki/Rheumatism "Rheumatism") and [arthritis](/wiki/Arthritis "Arthritis").^[\[383\]](#cite_note-383)^{#cite_ref-383}

In 1805, the [Vilnius Medical Society](/wiki/Vilnius_Medical_Society "Vilnius Medical Society") was established by [Joseph Frank](/wiki/Joseph_Frank_(physician) "Joseph Frank (physician)") (son of [Johann Peter Frank](/wiki/Johann_Peter_Frank "Johann Peter Frank")) as the first medical society in eastern Europe.^[\[384\]](#cite_note-384)^ The same year, the society established a [teaching hospital](/wiki/Teaching_hospital "Teaching hospital") ([clinic](/wiki/Clinic "Clinic")) as part of the Vilnius University Faculty of Medicine.^[\[385\]](#cite_note-385)^^[\[386\]](#cite_note-FirstClinic-386)^ From 1918 to 1941, the [Lithuanian Sanitary Aid Society](/wiki/Lithuanian_Sanitary_Aid_Society "Lithuanian Sanitary Aid Society") operated in Vilnius.^[\[387\]](#cite_note-387)^{#cite_ref-387}

The [Ministry of Health](/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Lithuania) "Ministry of Health (Lithuania)"), in Vilnius, is responsible for Lithuanian [health care](/wiki/Health_care "Health care").^[\[388\]](#cite_note-388)^ Vilnians pay compulsory [health insurance](/wiki/Health_insurance "Health insurance") (6.98 percent of their salary), which is governed by the Vilnius Territorial Health Insurance Fund and guarantees free health care to every insured person. Some residents, such as the disabled, children and full-time students, are exempt from the tax.^[\[389\]](#cite_note-389)^{#cite_ref-389}

[Vilnius University Hospital Santaros Klinikos](/wiki/Vilnius_University_Hospital_Santaros_Klinikos "Vilnius University Hospital Santaros Klinikos") and the Vilnius City Clinical Hospital are the city's primary [hospitals](/wiki/Hospital "Hospital").^[\[390\]](#cite_note-390)^^[\[391\]](#cite_note-391)^ Vilnius also has eight [polyclinics](/wiki/Polyclinic "Polyclinic"), the Medical Centre of the Ministry of the Interior, and a number of private health-care facilities.^[\[392\]](#cite_note-392)^{#cite_ref-392}

Media {#Media}
--------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Vilnius&action=edit&section=49 "Edit section: Media")\]
[![Title page of a 1760 newspaper](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Title_page_of_Kuryer_Litewski_newspaper_%281760%2C_Vilnius%29.jpg/170px-Title_page_of_Kuryer_Litewski_newspaper_%281760%2C_Vilnius%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Title_page_of_Kuryer_Litewski_newspaper_(1760,_Vilnius).jpg) Title page of *Kurier Litewski* (1760)

The first Lithuanian weekly newspaper, *[Kurier Litewski](/wiki/Kurier_Litewski "Kurier Litewski")* , was published in Vilnius from 1760 to 1763.^[\[393\]](#cite_note-393)^ Vilnius is home to a number of newspapers, magazines and other publications, including *[Lietuvos rytas](/wiki/Lietuvos_rytas "Lietuvos rytas")* , *[Lietuvos žinios](/wiki/Lietuvos_%C5%BEinios "Lietuvos žinios")* , *[Verslo žinios](/wiki/Verslo_%C5%BEinios "Verslo žinios")* , *[Respublika](/wiki/Respublika_(Lithuanian_newspaper) "Respublika (Lithuanian newspaper)")* , *Valstiečių laikraštis* , *Mokesčių žinios* , *Aktualijos* , *[15min](/wiki/15min "15min")* , *[Vilniaus diena](/wiki/Vilniaus_diena "Vilniaus diena")* , *Vilniaus Kraštas* , *[Lietuvos aidas](/wiki/Lietuvos_aidas "Lietuvos aidas")* , *[Valstybė](/wiki/Valstyb%C4%97 "Valstybė")* , *[Veidas](/wiki/Veidas "Veidas")* , *Panelė* , the Franciscan *[Bernardinai.lt](/wiki/Bernardinai.lt "Bernardinai.lt")* , the Russian *Litovskij kurjer* and the Polish *Tygodnik Wileńszczyzny* .^[\[394\]](#cite_note-394)^{#cite_ref-394}

The [Vilnius TV Tower](/wiki/Vilnius_TV_Tower "Vilnius TV Tower") in [Karoliniškės](/wiki/Karolini%C5%A1k%C4%97s "Karoliniškės") broadcasts to the city.^[\[395\]](#cite_note-395)^ The most-viewed networks in Lithuania are headquartered in Vilnius and include [LRT televizija](/wiki/LRT_televizija "LRT televizija"), [TV3](/wiki/TV3_Lithuania "TV3 Lithuania"), [LNK](/wiki/LNK_(television_station) "LNK (television station)"), [BTV](/wiki/BTV_(Lithuania) "BTV (Lithuania)"), [LRT Plius](/wiki/LRT_Plius "LRT Plius"), [LRT Lituanica](/wiki/LRT_Lituanica "LRT Lituanica"), [TV6](/wiki/TV6_(Lithuania) "TV6 (Lithuania)"), [Lietuvos rytas TV](/wiki/Lietuvos_rytas_TV "Lietuvos rytas TV"), [TV1](/wiki/TV1_(Lithuania) "TV1 (Lithuania)"), [TV8](/wiki/TV8_(Lithuania) "TV8 (Lithuania)"), [Sport1](/wiki/Sport1_(Lithuania) "Sport1 (Lithuania)"), [Liuks!](/wiki/Liuks! "Liuks!"), [Info TV](/wiki/Info_TV "Info TV").^[\[396\]](#cite_note-396)^{#cite_ref-396}
[![Very tall transmission tower, surrounded by smaller buildings](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/02/Vilniaus_televizijos_bok%C5%A1tas%2C_2023.jpg/220px-Vilniaus_televizijos_bok%C5%A1tas%2C_2023.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vilniaus_televizijos_bok%C5%A1tas,_2023.jpg) Vilnius TV Tower

Vilnius' first [radio station](/wiki/Radio_station "Radio station"), *Rozgłośnia Wileńska* , began broadcasting in the [Žvėrynas](/wiki/%C5%BDv%C4%97rynas "Žvėrynas") microdistrict on 28 November 1927 and was moved to present-day Gediminas Avenue in 1935.^[\[397\]](#cite_note-397)^ [M-1](/wiki/M-1_(Lithuanian_radio_station) "M-1 (Lithuanian radio station)"), the country's first commercial radio station, began broadcasting from Vilnius in 1989. Other Lithuanian or foreign-language radio stations also broadcast from Vilnius, most from the Vilnius TV Tower or the [Vilnius Press House](https://lt.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vilniaus_spaudos_r%C5%ABmai "lt:Vilniaus spaudos rūmai").^[\[398\]](#cite_note-398)^ The Lithuanian Union of Journalists (Lithuanian: *Lietuvos žurnalistų sąjunga* ) and the Lithuanian Society of Journalists (Lithuanian: *Lietuvos žurnalistų draugija* ) are headquartered in Vilnius.^[\[399\]](#cite_note-399)^^[\[400\]](#cite_note-400)^{#cite_ref-400}

2. **[\^](#cite_ref-2)** Widespread use of the nickname from the 16th century to this day as a reference to the many Catholic churches and monasteries in Vilnius and overall religious atmosphere in the centre. This nickname was/is used not only by foreigners but also by the local population. The 19th-century Lithuanian cultural figure [Dionizas Poška](/wiki/Dionizas_Po%C5%A1ka "Dionizas Poška") called Vilnius "Rome of the North", as, according to him, Vilnius is "the old religious centre, that transformed from a pagan city into the bastion of Christianity". D. Poška, *Raštai*, Vilnius, 1959, p. 67{#cite_note-2}
{#cite_note-2}
3. **[\^](#cite_ref-3)** Cultural newspaper, [It has been published in Vilnius since 1990, is named "Šiaurės Atėnai" (The Athens of the North)](http://www.satenai.) as a reference to one of Vilnius's nicknames, which was widespread in the first half of the 19th century and the first half of the 20th, mostly because of [Vilnius University](/wiki/Vilnius_University "Vilnius University"). During the interwar period, a Polish scientific newspaper published in Vilnius was also named "Atheneum Wileńskie".{#cite_note-3}
{#cite_note-3}

E.g.: S. Bodniak, "Polska w relacji włoskiej z roku 1604", Pamiętnik biblioteki kórnickiej, 2, (Kórnik, 1930), p. 37.{#cite_note-S._Bodniak_1930_p._37-4}
